“I am learning to ask,” I said, and this is a sentence that should have been a paragraph and the paragraph should have bought me several redeeming paragraphs more. “I am learning to ask if you want the spell I have. I am learning to hear no when I want to hear please. I am learning to start with please. I am learning to listen to the joke before I try to break it. I am learning that when you hold a mirror up and someone hates it, the thing to do is not shatter the mirror but offer it flat and walk away.”

It wasn’t triumph. It never is. The stories paid some of the bill and left a tip and still there was a penny under the chair that I would have to come back for. Brill showed up then. He had to. He is a creature of timing and cannot bear to miss his cue. He didn’t take a form. He moved through the crowd as a consensus. He said, in the voice of women who have been told their laugh is too much, “You think you are the first to discover honesty,” and a dozen of us snorted. He said, in the voice of men who have never been told they were pretty, “You think your tricks make you brave,” and a handful of kids said out loud, “No,” which made me want to throw my keys at the moon and ask for a new set for this place where children could answer back correctly.

He told us a joke about towns that rescue themselves and become smug about it. He told us a joke about cats that think they are charms. He told us a joke about librarians who fall in love with their own gospels. He put hooks under the words and then the hooks hit the purring and slid off, not because the purr was a shield, but because the room had learned a countermelody. He got bored. He looked for a glass to drop. There were none. He looked for a man whose mother had given him a name he hated. That man had left his name at home on purpose and brought a nickname he wore like a hoodie that smelled like bonfire.

Brill found me because he is compelled to. He spoke to the part of me that wants to be adored for usefulness and said, “I am going to give you your wish,” which is exactly wrong because I never wish out loud. He made the air smell like the inside of a bakery at three a.m. He made the bowl of milk I had not poured yet ache. He asked for my consent in the most honest voice I have ever heard him use. He said, “Let me turn you into what you make. Let me hold you. Let me show you that you cannot do this forever.”

There is a piece of Law that says if you are asked properly and you say yes, the aunties cannot step in and the uncles will turn their heads and the rings will pretend to be moss. Layla looked at me with a face that had all four punctuation magnets on it at once. Mr. Li placed a hand flat on the bench as if ready to test whether wood could carry a weight it hadn’t been built for. The kittens put one paw each on my shoe and waited in case I fell and needed to be braced by smallness.

“Not even for a minute?” Brill asked, and that is how the worst contracts are written: in minutes, in moments, in just until you’ve had your fill. I wanted it. Of course I did. I wanted to be small and carried and adored by fingers that try to resist but cannot. I wanted to know what I have been handing out all this time without ever taking a portion. I wanted to see whether I am all fur and bones or if there is something else underneath that will reach for you with claws out if you stop petting. I wanted him to know that he could be gentle, because I suspect it would ruin him.

“No,” I said, because it is a sentence with the weight of a cathedral if you lean your shoulder into it properly. “Not today. You are fun, but you are careless. I will not let carelessness do surgery on me.”

He laughed, genuinely, because saying no to him turns him on in the way that makes his eyes lose their color and get too human. He said, “Later,” and this time it wasn’t a threat or a promise; it was a fighting lesson. He left and took two mosquitoes with him, whose families will miss them and then be relieved.

We sat there in the after of it. People told their stories with the lights the city gives you for free—streetlamps and moon and the glow from a distant baseball diamond where men with generous bellies and complicated marriages try to feel exactly as important as they were when they were seventeen. We clapped and did not whistle because a whistle makes a spell you don’t want in a circle like this. The kittens dispersed with the air of creatures who have got tips in cash and in sardines. I washed the bowl at the standpipe behind the band shell and the water said thank you via a slant against my wrist. Layla stacked chairs with a competence that makes strong men propose and she declined none of them and all of them simultaneously by smiling with what she has instead of what she owes.

On the walk home the rabbits acted like they owned the sidewalk and I let them. A couple under a porch light kissed like they had not yet learned that the first kiss can be startling and then a map, and I did not look away, which is not rude, it is witness. The night had lost that strobe of impending. It wore a sweater. It was boring. I nearly wept with gratitude for the boredom of a Canadian suburb when the bad jokes are pointed at someone who can take them and take them apart.

My landlord had left a notice about water shutoffs for repairs that would not happen on the day indicated, and his cat had knocked it sideways so that it read WAR SHUF. She looked at me as if I had done it and I took the blame because you should always take the blame from someone who has whiskers and no thumbs. In the bathroom the whisker key rolled into my palm as if it had changed its mind about sulking. It vibrated in frequencies only my teeth understood. I sat on the edge of the tub and held it and said thank you without asking for a thing, and for once it hummed back without demanding a door.

I dreamt of a kitchen where every drawer had a secret I had put there and forgotten. I dreamt of a bus where every seat had a kitten and a man stood in the aisle and wept because he had found something that quieted the noise in him without asking him to punch holes in anyone else’s air. I dreamt of Brill as a boy who had not yet learned to operate his own elegance and who dropped it like a plate and cleaned it up clumsily and no one laughed. I woke to a morning that was an ordinary Monday. The radio talked about road closures and the price of avocados and the mayor’s latest attempt to make the city a verb. Layla texted: inventory day send help, and then: actually send croissants, and I sent both, because love is a choice and logistics.

The uncle had left a burr on my windowsill again. This one had a spider web in it that glittered in a way that I recognized as a hint. If you want to catch bigger problems, you make a bigger web, but you make the strands further apart so that the small things still go through. I put the burr by the whisker key and the mirror and the bowl and stood back and felt like a witch, which is not an insult where I come from. The Law tucked itself back into the cracks. The bill had a dent in it. I owed more, but not in a way that would eat me whole.

By lunchtime the headlines had multiplied like mushrooms: Community Cats Charm Crowd; Unauthorized Therapy Event Reported; Jokes Are Serious Business, Says Librarian; Local Fairy Declines To Be Cute, City Divided. I took the parcels to the library and let myself in the back and put the croissants on the shelf where Layla hides her victories. The children built a fort out of encyclopedias that are now written in pixels, and a boy with too many teeth said to me, solemnly, “We don’t need cats today because we have capes,” and I saluted him as if he’d outranked me. Brill sent me a picture on a number I had not given him of my whisker key with a caption: you’ll never open me, and I replied with a picture of a bowl of milk with none of my reflections in it and a caption: I don’t have to.

On the street outside the Finch a guy in a blazer practiced his apology to a door. It is a useful skill, apologizing to things. The used bookshop sign had finally given up on the B and proposed U SED OOKS, which is closer to a truth than you’d think. The storm drains breathed and forgot themselves and remembered. The summer leaned on its elbows and considered starting again. I had to go see Auntie Bellflower because she would not congratulate me and I needed the practice in being unpraised. I had to see Brill somewhere other than a room full of other people and stand near him without letting my pulse dictate the hour.

I took the milk with me because I am stubborn and because he had asked and because I had said no and because sometimes no has to be fed, too. In the ring the clover looked smug and the fence finally winked like I had gotten over myself. Auntie Bellflower sat on her mushroom with her tiny bone harp and a face like a poem that doesn’t resolve. “Well,” she said at once, to save us both from my report, and then, “Show me your hands.”

I showed her the palms I had held the night in and the fingers I had pointed at jokes, the nail with the burr sting under it and the callus that comes from carrying groceries instead of grief. She took them and turned them over and put one against her cheek like she was listening. “You paid some of it,” she said. “You’ll never pay all of it. That’s not the point.”

“What is the point,” I said, which is a question we ask each other at least once a month and then refuse to answer the same way twice.

“The point is that he tried to put the town in a room he had rented in his head, and you opened the windows,” she said, and then she flicked my ear for being pleased. “He is going to try again. He is going to bring cameras. He is going to ask you for small yeses until you are exhausted, and then he will ask you for a big one when you want to be adored. Do not make a habit of no. It will make you brittle. Make a habit of choosing.”

“I hate how you’re always right,” I said, which is worship in our family.

“Good,” she said. “Hate is a rope you can pull yourself up with. Love is a net. Use both. Bring milk. Bring mirrors. Bring Layla. Bring your landlord’s cat if she lets you. Teach the city the difference between a performance and a practice.”

On my way back out the mulberry tree dropped three ripe fruits on my shoulder on purpose and I put one in my mouth and it inked my tongue and tasted like sugar the first time you can afford your own grocery bill. The ring closed. The afternoon opened. Brill was somewhere doing something with someone else’s pity. The city was mine in the way it is anyone’s who decides to set their tools down and call a place a place they will defend. I went to the pond. Mr. Li waved. Children in sandbox grit made castles that would be destroyed by weather and felt, for once, both urgent and unimportant about that. The brass practiced the bridge of a song with a name that smelled like rain on concrete. I put the bowl on the bench and let the cats drink, which is an invitation and a refusal and a covenant and also a chore if you do it right, and believe me, I intend to do it right.Chapter Seven starts where ordinary picks itself up and goes to work again, which is to say the morning after felt like a Monday made out of lint and errands, but underneath it, the city had a buzz like a fluorescent tube when it’s about to go. The headlines laminated themselves to coffee shop tables as if anyone had ever been convinced by ink to change their mind. The kittens went back to being municipal punctuation marks. Layla texted me a picture of a flyer slapped crooked over the community corkboard between a call for babysitters and a guitar teacher: LAUGH-IN RICHMOND HILL! LIVE TAPING! SPECIAL GUESTS! CONSENT FORMS PROVIDED! The font had that particular optimism that smells like LED stage lights. It had Brill’s curve to it, the way the exclamation points leaned like they’d learned to do at his knee.

I had told Auntie Bellflower I would not make a habit of no, and I meant it, but I am capable of a beautiful and elaborate maybe. I walked to the library because that is where we plan our maybes; Layla had a spread of clipboards and pens and a stack of signs that couldn’t decide whether they wanted to be polite or effective. The children’s section hummed in the register where truth hides, low enough to calm but high enough to irritate anyone who came in looking for silence. We took the flyer and read it together like it might be willing to confess.

“He’s going to bring cameras,” she said, which was unoriginal and accurate.

“The cameras are not the problem,” I said. “The problem is the audience he thinks he is bringing with them. The problem is the laugh track he wants to splice in between us and our breath.”

“Then we seed our own audience,” she said, and set her mouth like a door you have to push because it sticks in humidity. “We make people who know where to place their laughter, who know how not to feed him, who know what to do when a consent form has teeth.”

“What do we teach first,” I asked, because we both know that the course you think you’re teaching is never the one people actually learn.

She took the flyer and flipped it over to the blank side—blank except for the faint smell of toner and the ghost of the exclamation points bleeding through like a premonition—and wrote: Rules For Watching Each Other. She did not number them, because numbering makes people argue with you in sequence. She wrote: listen before you laugh; and: if you can’t tell who the joke is for, it isn’t for you; and: if a form makes your stomach feel like a fist, don’t sign it alone. I added: you can always walk away even if the camera is on you; and: the world won’t end if you don’t give anyone a reaction.

We made copies and stocked the library with them as if they were immunizations and sent children home with one each tucked into their summer reading lists under a sticker with a turtle on a raft. The municipal worker whose shirt had said STAFF—Hardeep, as it turned out, with the soft H of a family that knows more than one language and speaks all of them with respect—came by on his lunch and took a handful of the sheets as if he were doing inventory for a shortage. He leaned on the desk like a man who had just discovered that bureaucracy comes with a conscience if you put your ear to it and rest there awhile.

“We’re going to be asked to issue a permit,” he said, giving me the expression of someone who doesn’t know whether he’s the messenger or the fuse. “If you can make it boring, that helps. If you can make it boring and fun, you’ll save me some paperwork.”

“I am the queen of boring and fun,” I said, and Layla snorted and then turned it into a cough because she has not yet made a habit of letting me be right in public.

The taping was slated for Hillcrest because nothing says civic like a mall pretending to be a piazza under skylights that pinch the sky into diamonds. In the hours between the flyer and the event, Brill did what he does best: he set table after table with little amuse-bouches of cruelty, small freebies that make you arrive hungry. The mall’s screens began to run a feed called YOU KNOW THAT FRIEND? and asked people to describe their friends in ways that would have gotten them exiled from rings in better eras. The loyalty points program sent a push notification to phones that said if you laughed out loud on camera today you could earn double points for purchases in categories called Confession and Indulgence. A kiosk near the food court hung a sign that read CONSENT STATION, where a very sweet woman with clipboard and smile offered releases that put your name into a wallet Brill could take home and spend without asking. We got there early, which is another way of saying we were already behind.

I wore the shoes I can stand in for hours without debating my own shins and a shirt that read LOCAL NOISE across the front because I had hopes for my subtlety and I have been wrong before. The whisker key hummed in my pocket like it wanted to introduce me to someone. The mirror lay wrapped in a scarf in my bag; I did not take it out because places like this have mirrors everywhere and none that work the way you need them to. Layla took her position at the library’s pop-up table we had elbowed between a phone case cart and a cupcake display; she made the Rules look like something you get for free and secretly would have paid for. Hardeep hovered near the potted tree that thinks it is outdoors and watched his fellow city employees unfold stanchions with the tenderness most people reserve for new babies.

Brill arrived later than he could have and earlier than he should, which is his favorite technique. He had traded his denim for a jacket that fit him as if he had grown inside it in a warm climate. He was not alone, because he is never alone in places like this; he was surrounded by a moving, breathing rig that looked like a spider one of our uncles might have dated in a bad period: arms out for microphones, eyes of glass and bright insect hunger, legs that bent where they don’t on humans. The production company had a name that would have embarrassed a deity but endeared a startup: LaughLines. A boy whose face was trying out the shape of beard carried the kind of camera that makes people think their lives were happening all along, they just hadn’t been filmed yet.

“Tammy-Tam,” Brill said, in the tone that makes people think you have already messed up and it is sweet he loves you anyway. “I see you brought pamphlets. I adore pamphlets. They make everyone look like they care.”

“We do care,” I said. “Which is why we print.”

He made his mouth into a shape I wanted to pinch and then stopped wanting to. “I have a segment called Ask The Town,” he said. “I ask the town: what’s funny because it’s true? And then I ask: what’s true because it’s funny? And then I ask: what happens if you stop pretending? You will love it. It will break nothing. Sign a form.”

“I will not sign a form I haven’t read backwards while standing upside down,” I said, and the camera boy snorted before he hid it. I like camera boys. They are always someone’s nephew and frequently think too much of lenses and not enough of eyes. He had a sticker on his water bottle that said the revolution will be livestreamed and I hoped for his sake he had a friend who had told him the revolution is also making dinner and doing dishes and calling your mother.

Layla placed a stack of the Rules on the consent station table. The sweet woman with the clipboard read one and looked relieved and slid it under her own forms as if it could be a cushion. Hardeep moved stanchions so that the crowd couldn’t bottleneck and become ugly; there is a magic to traffic control and some people practice it without spells. The mall pretended to be outdoors with more confidence and less ventilation than the real outdoors; the skylights made a lace of light and glare that gave everyone a halo and a headache.

The first person to be interviewed was a man in a shirt that read DAD JOKES LOADING, which made me want to buy him a better line and also hold his hand. He said something about marriage that could have landed harmless, and Brill absently sharpened it and tossed it into the air, and it cut the space and then fell point-first into a woman’s day ten feet away and she pretended not to bleed. I put my palm flat on the tile and told the mall to be a meadow. The tile did not know how. The plants in their pots tried to help and ended up inhaling a rumor and coughing.

I slid to the edge of the crowd and looped copper wire around a stanchion base because brass and copper and things that remember lightning are friends. I drew a thin line in chalk along the white seam between tiles as if I could remind the floor it had a spine. I set the bowl at my feet with water that had been milk in a recent life and watched the surface settle until it looked like it was thinking of me kindly. If you think all this is superstition, you are half right; the other half is logistics.

Brill started his segment. He asked a teenager what they were afraid to say online and the teenager said their parents’ names because those are the names the internet eats first. He asked a woman what she thought of the kittens and she said they made her cry and he made it sound like a punchline; it wasn’t. He looked at me out of the side of his life and said, “Do you believe in brave laughter?” because he knows how to make a room feel like it’s the test you didn’t study for. I opened my mouth to say the thing I had planned to say and he surprised me by putting his hands up like a man showing his pockets for a frisk and said, “Before you answer, a word from our sponsor,” and the cameras swung to a banner that had unrolled over the second-floor rail like a bad prophecy. It said: SOFTNESS ON DEMAND. Under it: Subscription kits for feelings; order now, get a free apology.

It is his vice and our shared season that he wants to commodify everything but refuses to allow himself to be priced. He smiled under the banner like a man walking his own joke down the aisle. I could have stood there and been irritated and given him a better show. Instead, I stepped sideways into the back hallways where the mall keeps its bones: the service corridor with the smell of dust and freight, pipes above hissing reminders that water goes where it is told until it doesn’t. The camera boy saw me and did not follow because something in him has not been completely colonized by content. I found the door with the keyhole that looks like a yawn and told the whisker key to try its teeth.

It hummed like a tuning fork finally tapped by the correct impatience. The door did not open into a room, because rooms are nothing here. It opened into the place where the mall’s nervous system talks to itself, where the routers blink in self-importance and the bundles of cable lie like snakes pretending to nap. It sounded like a thousand bees explaining civics. It felt like a comment section through your shirt.

“Hello,” I said, because if I have learned anything, it is that manners are a tool and a shield and occasionally a sword. The network recognized the flavor of my voice because Layla had taught it boredom and I had taught it to expect biscuits. A wall of screens flickered to show a mirror of the mall from moments ago; you could see Layla’s hand as it arranged someone’s fear into a stack that would not topple. You could see Brill’s joke clotting at the corners. You could see a red circle in the corner of a screen that meant people in other places would be watching soon.

Consent in a place like this is a box you check and a vein you open. I walked along the racks and told each one: matte. I slid the copper wire under a switch and told it: be polite. I put my palm against a fan and told it: keep secrets unless asked. The whisker key sang when I came to the node that smelled of his mouth. It wasn’t a possession so much as a fondant he had spread across the code to make it take his fingerprints. I took the mirror out of the scarf and held it so that the machine could see itself. There is a rumor that computers cannot see; it is false. They see themselves in the greed of their designers and the shame of their users. They see and they forget. I made this one remember.

The feed on the screen stuttered. The moving rig out in the atrium jerked as if someone had tugged a string in its spine. I heard, faintly through the vents, the crowd noise fall a notch as if the kind of laughter that hurts had been told to wait its turn and be registered. A supervisor in a high-visibility vest came into the room behind me and said, “You can’t be in here,” and I said, “You are correct,” and kept my hand on the fan until it hummed Yes, Auntie. He stood like a man in a dream who has not yet decided whether to be furious or to be new. He looked at the bowl of milk under the rack—the bowl I had not carried with me and yet was present, white and useful—and made the face of someone who just remembered being a child fed by a tired hand. “Don’t spill,” he said, because that is a sentence that, in an emergency, can save a world.

When I came back into the atrium, the banner had been unfurled a second time and the unsubtle noun phrasing had realigned itself to be less a threat and more a question: SOFTNESS, ON PURPOSE? The consent table had two lines: one to sign and one to unsign, and the unsigning line was longer. I stood next to Layla and smiled at the camera because sometimes putting your face in the thing takes the sting out of it. Brill held the microphone and did not look surprised or pleased. He looked like a man who has been handed a wrench and told there was a leak and now has to decide whether he is the kind of person who learns to fix a leak or the kind who makes jokes about plumbers.

“Ask your town,” I said to him, low enough that only the microphone and he could hear me. “Ask it with tenderness and see what you get. If you ask with barbs, you’ll get blood and think it’s wine. You’re better at this than that.”

“I am better at what I am better at,” he said, and there was a ripple of real hurt there that made me want to stroke something on him and also slap it away. “Do your trick. Make me a kitten. Give us the clip.”

“I don’t need the clip,” I said, and he smiled; it is his cruelty that he admires the correct refusal even when it denies him a weapon. “I will answer your segment instead.”

He swung the mic toward me like a baton. The camera boy focused and then relaxed his shoulders because someone had told him once that tension shows through the lens and he had believed them. “Tamsin,” Brill said into the camera in his honey that tastes more like sugar the second day it’s open, “believes in brave laughter. Tell us about that.”

“Brave laughter,” I said, like it was a animal I had sometimes fed and sometimes chased off my porch, “is when you hear the worst idea in you say hello and you don’t feed it. Brave laughter is when you laugh after you have done the work, not before. Brave laughter is when the person next to you feels their shoulders drop because your laugh did not include the cost of their dignity. Brave laughter is when you step away from the joke and don’t point to say who should take your place under it. Brave laughter is when you notice the heckler in your own head and say, not today, you little creep, I’m making soup.”

People laughed at the word soup, which is proof that there is still hope. The mall hummed. The production rig took its teeth out in order to swallow. Brill gave me the microphone, which meant he had lost the thread he had wanted to braid and was considering whether to cut it or make a friendship bracelet out of it. He whispered, just for me, “You are so good on camera,” and I whispered back, “That is your fault,” and his smile did a complicated math it isn’t polite to watch.

He pivoted, because that is his salvage. He found a man in a suit with hotel confidence and asked him, “What’s your truest laugh?” The man did the thing men do when asked to be sincere in front of strangers and ordered a joke like it was a drink. Brill waited, which is not a habit of his, and when the man gave up and shrugged, allowed something gentle into his tone and asked, “Did anyone make you laugh when you were small?” The man said, “My sister,” with a softness that reminded his tie of rainfall, and he told a story about a time they had hidden under the table during a flood—not a real flood, a plumbing catastrophe—and made faces at each other until the adults calmed down. It was not cruel. It was almost kind. The crowd made a hum of relief like a building settling into itself after being tipped. The camera boy checked his frame and exhaled like he had found a song he had been trying to remember for days.

The segment did not turn virtuous; nothing ever does that quickly. A kid wanted to show off and said something about librarians that would have made a lesser woman murder by etiquette, and Layla put her elbow on the table and said, imperturbable, “Try again,” and the kid tried again and did better and got a sticker that said REVISED and was proud of it. The consent station gave a couple their forms back with staples and advice. Hardeep moved the stanchions like a shepherd who had discovered that flocks will sometimes tell you where they need to go if you give them choice. Brill slipped jokes under doors and I wedged my foot in where I could and caught them before they hit the ankles of people who were tired.

When it was done, which is to say when the mall’s afternoon said I have to pick up my kids and go to karate now, Brill came over and leaned on the table and examined the Rules like they were insect wings pinned to cork. He tapped the line about walking away with his middle finger and smiled without teeth. “You can’t teach them to walk away from me,” he said, and I could have told him that the town had taught itself to walk away from worse with fewer pamphlets, but I am trying to cultivate not being cruel. “You have to offer something to walk towards.”

“We did,” Layla said, not looking at him. “Books. Each other. Soup.”

He did his bow that says either you have my attention or I am making room to run. The rig breathed around him and he exhaled with it as if to teach it to be human. “Tonight?” he said to me, because he likes to pretend evenings are his alone. “Under the bridge? Or do you need a bandshell to feel brave?”

“Tonight,” I said, “where it is quiet, where we can hear ourselves,” and he winced in theatrical pain because he hates to give up witnesses even for a minute. He glanced at the camera boy, and the boy nodded and tucked his camera in its foam as if he had been told he was off the hook and given a lollipop besides.

The bridge runs over the little river that believes vehicles are more temporary than stones. The graffiti under it tries hard to be a liturgy and the damp there is benevolent unless your shoes have secrets. I brought my bag and my bowl and my mirror and my key, which is to say I brought the Mars and the Venus and the Saturn of my little solar system. Layla did not come because this was not her fight and also because she promised to come if I did not come home by eleven and call the cops, which is friendship in a town where the cops do not know what to do with fairies and cats and jokes except write reports that sound oddly like field notes.

He came out of the darkness like he had always lived there and we were visitors who had to speak politely. The water made its complicated vowels and the cars overhead spoke in consonants. The mosquitoes held a tiny union meeting and agreed to leave us alone in exchange for blood later from joggers who call themselves runners and are right. He wore a jacket and no shirt because he likes to be dramatic about climate and because his chest is an argument he thinks he can win. I looked at the bridge piles, at the marks where ice had scoured last winter like fingernails on a table, and put my bowl down without making a ceremony of it.

“I will ask you again,” he said, as if I had been the one who wanted him to. “Let me turn you into what you make.”

“Not tonight,” I said, in the tone you use when you do not want the night to become a character.

He tilted his head and smiled and shook his hands out as if he had to throw off applause that did not exist. “Then tell me a secret,” he said. “Tell me one that costs you and feeds me.”

“I did that already,” I said. “You were there and you took notes.”

He took one step closer like a man testing a sheet of ice, and I felt the desire to be nice rise in me like a fog. I put the mirror up to my own mouth and said, “No,” and watched it grow simpler on the glass. He made a noise the city sometimes makes when it learns it cannot bend a river: pretty and petty and pleased to be resisted. He perched on the low wall and let his ankles dangle over water that knows your name longer than your friends do.

“You are practice,” he said. “That is your charm. People know what to do around you. You put things in order, even the soft things. I am performance. I make things happen when they should not and everyone is grateful or angry and cannot tell which is which.”

“You say that like it makes us equals,” I said, because I can be mean when I have to remind him that he is not my match just because he wants to be.

He leaned forward like a cat offered lemon. “Do not get arrogant,” he said, and it cut enough that I understood he had seen me puff and chose to cut me down rather than adore me back to decent size. “The town loves you because you are useful. It loves me because I am dangerous. We can trade positions any time and hate each other anyway.”

“Do you want to trade,” I asked, as if it were a question with answers instead of a rhetorical letter to a god who never does his own work.

He looked at the water and remembered it had once let him drown a duke without letting the duke die. He looked at me and remembered my hands on the neck of a kitten who was also a boy who was also a story. He sighed, which is what he does when he wants to be human. “I want you to stop being my conscience,” he said.

“I want you to stop needing one,” I said.

He laughed, and the bridge vibrated in sympathy. “There will be cameras at your story nights next time,” he said, not quite warning. “They will come without my invitation.”

“Then we will teach them what applause is for,” I said. “It’s for thank you, not for please more pain.”

A train went by far enough away that its sound arrived like advice from an uncle you respect and dislike. He watched it as if it were an animal he might someday learn to be. “Bellflower will say she cannot help you,” he said. “She will then help you anyway and pretend it was an accident. You will say you do not want to be praised and then you will hoard good words like a thrift store that only sells compliments. You will make a mistake on purpose to relieve the pressure and then hate yourself for failing. I will watch you and know that I am watching for the moment you forgive yourself and I will hate you for being capable of doing that.”

“That is accurate,” I said, which is why I have to talk to him sometimes: he names the ugly correctly and then decides it is a cologne. “There is a child in our town who will one day try to be you. I am trying to make it so that when they try, they choose me instead.”

He flinched as if I had offered to cut off his hand. “Leave them to me,” he said, and I did the noise in my throat that raccoons make when you try to put them in a bag.

“Go home,” I said, and it sounded like a prayer again because so much of what I have learned to say to him comes out of churches I refuse to admit to. He didn’t. He left because his body has a calendar that says it is time to go when the moon reaches a certain slant on the bridge’s concrete. He left because staying would have made us something we are not. He left and the water congratulated itself on being water and not wine.

When I got back to my building, the landlord’s cat was sitting on the steps like a judge waiting to be asked for leniency. She looked at me in that way of cats that says I know everything and will tell you nothing and also my bowl is empty. I filled her bowl because you owe the gods of your street their sacrifices. The notice about water shutoffs had been replaced with one about filming; our block was going to be a location for a scene where two actors in jackets too thin for their season would argue about whether to take a job in Montreal. I took a pen and wrote underneath: no filming between the hours of four and six because that is when the lashes of the neighborhood curl and we are at our most beautiful, and someone below my handwriting wrote: agreed.

At home the houseplants had leaned toward the window in a way that made it look like they were gossiping about my choices. I set the mirror face down because I needed it to stop telling the room that I exist. The whisker key rolled on the table until it lay with its handle against the burr the uncle had left; the spider web glinted there and made a geometry that whispered: bigger web, wider holes, catch only what you intend. I texted Layla a heart and a fox and a cat and she sent back a horseshoe and a coffee cup and the string of letters that means I am too tired to call you but I know what you did.

The next day the cameras came to story night without anyone’s invitation because that is what they do now: they arrive at places where people are trying something difficult and ask for ten seconds out of context. We had prepared. Hardeep had borrowed stanchions and stood them not to corral people but to mark the visible edges of our circle. The brass had polished their bells and practiced a soft double-tongue that sounds like rain you forgot about because you were laughing. Layla had added to the sign: No Filming Of Other People Without Asking, and underneath that: All Stories Are Owned By The Mouths That Tell Them. Mr. Li had brought two thermoses and a dozen porcelain cups because paper cups breed a certain thoughtlessness we were fresh out of patience for.

The camera boy showed up with his lens cap on and his moral compass functioning. He had brought two friends who looked like they had been told to capture authenticity and were trying not to flinch. Brill did not come; he had done his show and had a date somewhere with a person who thinks they can read him. The kittens came as if the word had spread that gentle might happen again. The children wore capes and Gatorade moustaches. The municipal worker set down his jacket and helped an auntie drag a bench into the shade because the late-day sun had decided we were a parade and wanted to inspect us.

I went first because sometimes that is the work, and told a short story about a time when I was a child and thought a thunderstorm was my fault because I had yelled at the sky for being so blue it made me miss the lake. People laughed where it helped and didn’t where it didn’t. The cameras stayed back and shot wide. A boy read a poem about his grandmother’s hairnet that made Layla cry a little and a woman told a joke that made Hardeep almost drop a cup and the kittens took it all in as if it were a heat lamp. The microphones, if they were on, captured the purr. It was an effect you could sell if you had no soul.

A man stepped into the circle without raising his hand and announced that he was a comedian and had notes for us. He used the word freedom three times with different intonations. He believed that the phrase punching up has only two axes. He did not read the sign. He began an anecdote about women in bookstores that was not going to end well for women or for bookstores. Layla stood and said, “No thanks,” and he looked at her with the face men make when they are about to quote a First Amendment and then remembered we are in Canada and flailed for a Charter of Rights and Freedoms he had not read recently. I put my hand up gently and said, “You’re at the wrong venue,” and the crowd did not jeer because they have learned how to not feed him even when he looks hungry.

The cameras rolled and we made something worth rolling on. A woman who had never spoken in public told us about the time she laughed at a wake and how it saved three people. A kid forgot the end of his story and the brass put in a comma that turned into an ending all on its own. A librarian who is not Layla but who owes Layla the same debt we all do admitted to stealing time to read when she was a girl and the way the stolen time tasted like mint gum and guilt. We applauded where it mattered and let the space between the applause be the lesson. The camera boy took off his cap and put it over his heart once and I forgave him some future trespass.

After, when the sun had done that thing where it is still light and yet the day is over, Brill texted me a picture of himself drinking milk with a caption: practicing, and I sent back a picture of my whisker key lying on the burr with a caption: same. Auntie Bellflower sent a leaf through the mail slot and it landed on the mirror and made it look like a pond with a lily on it, and I felt the city sigh like it had done its stretches and could now go to sleep without nightmares. I am not foolish enough to think that lasts. But I am brave enough to set a bowl on the bench and fill it and invite the town to drink tenderness on purpose, and I am stubborn enough to wash that bowl every time until the ring around it tells a story I can live with.

There is still a bill in my mouth. There is still a clip coming where someone catches me from an angle that makes me look like everything I say I am not. There is still the child Brill will try to shape and the night he will show up with the men who like to test their knuckles. There is still the winter and the willow and the boy whose name I pull back through sap and the friend I turned soft when she needed to be sharp and how I will someday ask her to forgive me with her edge intact. There is soup to make. There are spiders to thank. There is a mall to keep matte. There is a bridge to walk by without making it a symbol every time. There is this town that thinks it is a cul-de-sac and is actually a crossroad disguised as a cul-de-sac so you don’t panic when you find yourself here. There is me. There is him. There is a bowl. There is a key. There is a mirror. There is a laugh that doesn’t hurt anyone and I am going to teach it to as many mouths as I can before we run out of summer.

I slept that night like a cat in a laundry basket, which is to say with my spine arranged in a way that would alarm a chiropractor and my heart near the clean things. In the morning the radio said there had been a minor incident at Hillcrest in which a banner changed its own punctuation and no one was harmed. The used bookshop sign had lost the B altogether, which left U SED O OKS, which I chose to translate as You seed oaks, which is a message I took more personally than it was intended. A man at the bus stop smiled at me and said, “Hey, aren’t you—” and I said, “Yes, I live here,” and he nodded like that was all anyone ever wanted to be famous for. On the ring, the clover did its self-satisfied hiss and the fence winked, and the aunties neither praised nor scolded me, which is better than a cake if you are made the way I am. I put the bowl down and poured out what we had. A kitten came and drank and then looked at me with the face of a creature who has already forgiven me for the next mistake and I told it, steady now, I am learning to make fewer of those.Chapter Nine

The day began with a sky the color of a fresh eraser, soft and stubborn and apt to smudge, and the radio trying to convince me that rush hour is an animal that can be domesticated if you speak to it in a soothing tone. The used bookshop sign had finally surrendered its B and was trying out personalities—U SED O OKS at dawn, USE DOOKS by nine—like a teenager testing hair. On my way to the library a wind lifted napkins and made paper birds out of other people’s lunches, and a bus sighed in three keys, and every sound seemed to be rehearsing for something I did not yet have a ticket to. The bill in my mouth—the one you bite and keep under your tongue so you don’t spend it by accident—had shrunk enough that I could taste coffee around it, which felt like a mercy and a setup, because Brill is not a creature who enjoys leaving change on the counter.

At the children’s desk Layla had turned clipboards into a fort and was issuing pencils like passports, and the paper cranes above her were arranging themselves into phrases by accident: BE KIND, BE QUIET, BE K— and then giving up because the ceiling fan liked mischief more than messages. Hardeep had wandered over on his break to confess a dream in which all the stanchions in the city had learned to walk away when people tried to line them up, which is a metaphor you can put in your pocket and carry for later. Mr. Li arrived at eleven with lychees in a plastic bag and the satisfaction of a man who had gotten three small things to do as they were told and forgiven a fourth for not. We read a flyer together that had colonized the corkboard between dog-walker ads and piano lessons: ROAST ON THE GREEN: A NIGHT OF TRUTH AND LAUGHTER WITH SPECIAL GUESTS; CONSENT FORMS OPTIONAL, which is to say not optional at all, and the font had Brill’s swagger in its swash and a production company’s fingerprints all over its spine.

“We can’t un-host,” Layla said, which is how she says the word boycott when the audience is children and aunties and the mall teenager who stares with that expression like you owe them the next plot twist and your inside pocket lint as interest. “But we can re-host. We can throw a thing next to their thing and teach the city not to go where their feet don’t want to.”

“We feed the town before he serves dessert,” Mr. Li said, and exactly three children who were building a castle out of damaged encyclopedias chorused, “Soup,” as if they had been waiting for their cue for weeks. Hardeep frowned the way only a municipal worker with a soul can frown and said he would see if he could find those portable bollards that make a space feel like someone whispered “behave” in its ear. I suggested we build a tent that says BOAST & TOAST and sell nothing and pour tea and ask people for their best thing of the week, which is not a joke and not a confession and not something cameras can use without getting their mouths sweet and sticky. Layla nodded and wrote rules on the back of a discarded Smiley Face poster so the Smiley looked like it had opinions about ethics, and she wrote: brag about yourself without stepping on a throat; listen until you can repeat someone else’s sentence correctly; no punches, no punchlines, no punching down.

The ring behind the fence had grown suspicious enough of my good mood to hiss a little when I passed, and the fence blinked the slow blink of furniture learning not to be furniture. Auntie Bellflower was not on her mushroom, which means she was either saving a creek from a culvert or stringing a thread between two lovers too proud to ask for it. An uncle with a beard like a thistle and the eyes of someone who knows where all the basement doors are sat with his shoes off, toes in the wrong clover, and he acknowledged me by not ignoring me, which in our family is fondness in its wool sweater. He tilted his head and considered the way I was standing on my own shadow and asked if I had eaten anything more substantial than opinions. I said I had chewed a headline until it tasted like cardboard and he sighed as if we were discussing my calcium intake. When I told him about the roast and the green and the consent forms that thought they were gentlemen, he shrugged in the resigned style of men who have seen jokes break kingdoms and shoestring budgets alike.

“You can’t braid a whip out of laughter and then be surprised when it finds someone’s back,” he said, and I told him he was late with his poetry and we had already made signs. He inspected my bag, which is nosy and rude but permitted under the statute that reads: uncles rummage; nieces steal; aunties pretend not to notice. When his fingers found the whisker key, it shivered like a greyhound that has learned the meaning of a doorbell, and he grunted approval, which is as close as an uncle gets to bless you unless you’ve lost a finger. “You are about to do something you will be praised for and then blamed for and then forgotten for until someone needs you in a hurry,” he said, and that is prophecy when it comes from a mouth that has chewed nettles.

“I could use a trick,” I said, which is how we say please in my line, because the words that get used too often wear holes in them and look indecent. He scratched his beard and arranged his face into a map and taught me a thing you do with your hands when you want to be smaller without being less, a letting-out of seams that does not change your size but changes how the world sits on you. “Try wearing your paws on the inside,” he said, and when I rolled my eyes at him he did something impossible and meowed at a pitch you only hear in alleys and rings. The wrong clover shook itself, which is how it laughs. “You’ve never been on all fours,” he said, which is not true if you consider childhood, but true if you consider the habit I’d made of standing for other people.

I did not say yes to being a kitten and handed to someone I could not predict; I have enough sense left to dose my curiosity with a dropper. I said yes to a pawfast, is what he called it: an afternoon with the edges of me fluffed and my joints convinced they could turn both ways if they didn’t hesitate. I walked back through the gate with my dignity tucked under one arm and my aftercare already an ache. The world did not tilt the way it does when you change size, because I did not. The world smelled louder, which is the thing you never remember to say when you tell stories about cats. The sawhorse on the sidewalk had a maple’s breath on it and the bus shelter had sighed so often it had learned a human tone, and every child had a voice around their laughter that said I have eaten something sweet and hope I will not be scolded.

No one petted me because I wear the shape of a woman who can turn men to kittens in a blink, and people in this town are learning not to touch even when they want to, and the discipline sits beautifully on them and will look even better when it stops being a novelty. What happened was stranger and less showy: the edges of everything softened in me. The part of me that flinches when I hear cutlery chime in a way that forecasts cruelty did not flinch. The part that gets impatient with waiting in line because I can hear how tired the cashier’s feet are decided to be bored in a kind way, a pocket-sized boredom that does not make the air crack. With the paws on the inside, everyone looked newly edible and newly sacred, which is a dangerous mood and one I did not wear for longer than it took me to buy milk and carry it without drinking out of the carton. It was, perhaps, the best rehearsal I could have asked for in a city that would soon be asked to treat cruelty as content again.

By afternoon the town’s nervous system had been salted with something Brill had taught it, and the bus bell had learned to deliver rimshots, and the cash register at the drugstore had started pronouncing totals in a voice that was a little too smug, and a pair of benches by the fountain had taken to giggling when teenagers sat on them, which made the teenagers feel seen in the wrong register and get loud in the wrong direction. My copper wire went where copper likes to go, under bolts and along sills and in pockets where electricity thinks it is safe from aunties and uncles. I un-taught the benches to titter by telling them a very boring story about waiting rooms and the way chairs who do their jobs correctly get thanked with no notice, and I made the bus bell find the note that means we have arrived and not the one that means someone is about to say something mean, and the cashier—who had been braced for people to perform for a breaker box—exhaled into her sleeve and belonged to herself for at least the next five minutes.

By sunset the green was a mouth and the stage was a tongue, and the speakers looked like teeth, and this is why I prefer ponds and band shells and those half-constructed amphitheaters where a town keeps meaning to make music and runs out of budget. LaughLines had built a rig that could lift five jokes and lower five reputations simultaneously, and the stanchions had been set to allow for people to leave but to feel sheepish about it, which is a spell even when it’s just rope on metal posts. We placed our tent three trees over, where a grandmother’s shadow had always lived, and strung it with paper lanterns that glowed the color of almost-ripe peaches, and the sign read BOAST & TOAST in letters that had been to preschool and learned to share. Layla had put out the Rules next to a basket of markers and the markers had recorded a dozen children teaching each other to draw stars without lifting the tip, which is a curriculum any school should adopt.

The brass warmed their lips in a corner and looked like they were telling their instruments secrets they’d promised to see safely home. Mr. Li set the thermos on a crate painted blue and poured out tea as if that were the only thing anyone needed, and the citizens of a town that tries to be modest and sometimes succeeds approached the tent like they had never been allowed before to brag without hurting anything. I opened the mirror and faced it down on the table like a fox sleeping, and set the bowl where cats could find it and where children could see that this was not a trick but a kind of altar. Hardeep moved through the crowd like a person dreaming of being useful and finding he was awake. I watched people try to laugh at the roast stage and discover their mouths did not want to open that way, which is a lesson and a miracle and a credit to months of practice no one put on a calendar.

Brill took the stage like a man who has finally found a suit that fits him both standing and sitting, and his smile was an apology to the air for what he was about to do with it. He brought comics who had flown in and worn their jet lag like a crown and were spoiling for a fight with any town that thinks it loves itself. He asked for our worst selves and the audience did what he trained them to do in other places: they participated, because we have taught ourselves that participation is the form kindness takes in a busy world. He asked for my name and the green said it in the two wrong ways and the right way, and the right way sounded like a kettle catching, and he took it and balanced it on his tongue like a coin he might swallow with the flourish of a bad magician. He told a line about a woman who turns men into kittens to get out of arguments, which is a joke anyone can write if they refuse to look at the parts of an argument that cannot be solved by claws.

I could have made him stop, right there, with the softest push. I could have tied the punchlines into bows and handed them back to their owners with a smile that said please do not. I did not. I stepped up onto the green’s lip and I told the third strand in the shape it deserved, no names and all edges, because the Law likes to be fed properly and because the roast audience had come fasting and thought their hunger made them noble. When I said I had turned a friend soft in public when she needed to crack the air with her full bald fury and that I had stolen her moment to be seen as dangerous by being tender instead, the far bench squeaked and then learned to be quiet. When I said I loved someone in ways that looked like help and were a way of keeping myself necessary, the man in the hotel suit looked at his phone as if it had begun to tell the truth. When I said I apologized to the air because the person does not owe me her forgiveness and I would not accept it as payment if she offered, Layla put her hand on the table and the paper lanterns gathered themselves and glowed steadier without anyone adjusting their strings.

The roast stage tried to turn it into a bit, and the bit found no foothold in a field where the grass had been taught the difference between bones and boneshed. It rained a little at that moment, because weather loves an act break, and the microphones did their little tinnitus dance and then healed. One of the visiting comics took a run at the kittens and found his feet on gravel, because you cannot step on something that has decided to be fluid, and another tried to sell us the truth as if it were a craft beer and the crowd remembered that truth is not a taste but a practice and went to our tent and wrote in marker “I took a nap and it saved my life,” and a stranger applauded because you must.

It would have been enough to leave it there—the roast starving, the boast fed, the town making a decision that looked like a yawn and was actually a vow—but there is an inertia to men like Brill and a kindness to me that makes me a little stupid, and those two forces meet like weather fronts over a small region that has learned to keep sandbags in the garage. He did the thing he promised in whispers and rehearsal spaces, not with the full apparatus of a show but with the intimacy he reserves for our worst impulses; he asked me again, in front of no one, with his mouth in the modest shape of consent, if I would let him turn me into what I make. He did not raise his eyebrows and he did not smirk, which is how I knew he was serious and how he knows to make me consider doing something reckless and honest.

The bridge at Hillcrest is a bridge only to teenagers; the rest of us call it a walkway. He found me there on the way to carrying the thermos back with Mr. Li’s careful arm, and we stood in a wind tunnel that smelled faintly of cinnamon from the donut place and faintly of wet cement from the fact of being in a suburb that keeps rebuilding itself like a nervous habit. He said the word please as if it scrapes him, which is how I know he practices it in the mirror sometimes and hates what it does to his reflection. I touched my mirror to my own mouth and watched the no become smaller and more useful and less of a defense and more of a tool. He flinched and asked whether I was afraid of finding out what I hand people; I told him I am not afraid of tenderness but of addiction, and his face did the small honest wince of someone who recognizes their own species.

He left me with a joke folded into a consent form, which is his idea of romance and sabotage, and I folded it back and returned it to the woman at the clipboard, who had learned by then to staple every form to a copy of our Rules so that people who signed away their names at least took home a list of instructions for breathing. I went back to the green and watched a child teach another child to clap on two and four and saw a man stop himself from filming without asking because we had printed in blue sharpie, by hand, a sentence that said: all stories are owned by the mouths that tell them, and I watched it sink into his pocket like a coin worth keeping.

At home after, the houseplants had put their leaves exactly where they wanted them and were uninterested in my opinion, which is a stage of maturity we can all aspire to. The whisker key lay on its back and hummed at whatever frequency it uses when it is proud and sulky and impatient, and I set the burr next to it and threaded the spider web through two teeth until it looked like a harp for a very small ghost. I wrote a note to Auntie Bellflower that said I spent more truth than I had and still have credit and I hate you for making me enjoy that and also come over and take my mirror for a week because I should learn to look at people without needing it. The window wore the neighborhood in a shy brightness and the landlord’s cat sprawled on the steps like a judge who had learned mercy was a job and not a hobby, and I slept with my hands open so that I would not wake up clutching anyone I had no right to hold.

The cameras came back the next night and found a town that had learned to ask before telling, and a boy who had taped our Rules to his skateboard and was riding in loops that made his parents nervous and his future less frightening, and a librarian who had taped the same Rules inside the Choice Reads display and added in smaller letters, as if to herself and us all: it is okay to leave in the middle. Brill sent me a picture of a milk ring around his mouth and the caption practice makes peril and I sent him a picture of my empty bowl in a sink full of suds and the caption practice makes dishes and he left it on read, which is a courtesy in our era and may count as truce. Hardeep emailed a draft bylaw with a note that said you didn’t see this and it protects nothing and everything and makes filming require tea service, and I laughed in the way that feeds your body and does not nibble at your soul, and I said yes to the meeting because the Law likes paperwork dressed like affection.

There are other chapters ahead where I will do something small and be thanked too large, and nights when Brill will find a seam in an auntie I thought seamless and pull and I will have to put my hand there and ask for patience as a verb and not a trait. There is winter coming whether or not anyone wants it and the willow will need to be reminded that she is not responsible for the whole lake. There is a child practicing the timing on a joke that could break him or make him, and I will have to be there with a bowl and a mirror and the willingness to be told no. There is this town with its light industrial parks and its ponds and its generous garbage raccoons and its ambulatory stanchions and its sly bookshop sign, and I will seed oaks where I can and apologize to air when I cannot and make soup on nights when there is nothing else to do and invite the cats and hope the cameras are bored. I am not finished paying. He is not finished trying. Between us is the practiced laugh that doesn’t hurt and the practiced no that doesn’t punish, and the summer is longer than it looks if you nap in it correctly.Chapter Ten

Morning ran its tongue along the edges of the town and tasted dust and berry. The used bookshop sign had decided to be USE OOKS for an hour and then changed its mind to YOU SEE OAKS, which made me want to plant something and apologize to the dirt in advance. The radio tried to sell me a mattress and a municipal consultation and then a woman’s laugh came through my phone like a coin dropping from nowhere: a clip of me, framed like a specimen and captioned FAIRY DECLINES CUTENESS. Someone had cut my “Not today” and looped it so I sounded coy and precious in a way that would make me punch a wall if I liked drywall. The comments were what comments always are: hungry. There were requests that I kitten a boss and a husband and a judge. There were threats dressed as compliments asking what it would take to make me say yes. There were a few kind words from people who have found that saying no rescued their lives and they had been waiting to clap for someone who did it in public, and those I tried to save and not drink, because someone else might need them.

I put the phone face down on the table and set the mirror on top of it so the glass would keep glass company and maybe they would teach each other a little humility. The whisker key rolled itself off the tea towel I had laid out as a stage and thunked its head against the bowl and made a noise like a small bell with an attitude. Layla texted: we need signs for tonight; also muffins, and I texted back: muffins first, ethics after, and she sent a picture of a child asleep inside a fort made of non-circulating atlases with a caption that read: good, because I’ve been doing ethics since 8.

At the bakery the croissants were a rumor at the back and the front case was a sermon: plum galettes that made my mouth feel like it remembered orchards I have never harvested, sesame buns glossy with ambition, a sourdough that had split its crust laughing. The girl behind the counter had a ring on her thumb that made her look like she could open bottles with her smile, and I watched a man try to make a joke land on her like a tip. I slid into the space between the words and the way they wanted to go and said, lightly, “That one’s tired,” and he blinked and swapped out his script for a better one that involved please and exact change and a compliment about the bake that did not involve her body. I carried muffins like a rumor you want to spread carefully and told myself that the clip will be forgotten by dinner and then remembered again on a bus at midnight by someone who needed permission, and that has to be enough.

The board outside the library read STORY NIGHT: EVERYONE GETS A TURN, and under it Layla had chalked in a tiny, stubborn hand: no filming without asking, and under that someone had added: no asking without meaning it. Hardeep stood at the returns desk like a man who had to confess he loved being in a place where children are issued cards without their utility accounts attached, and he slid me a draft of a bylaw tucked under a newspaper like it was contraband. “It would be a pilot,” he said, eyes on the door because he is good at being seen as boring, “A requirement for public events to provide tea and quiet corners. Less a rule than a reminder that we are a people, not a feed.”

“A tea clause,” I said, and the joy of it hit me so hard I had to set the muffins down and put my hand on a shelf because my knees were weak. “You are making bureaucracy into a kind of auntie.”

“It was either that or stanchions with feelings,” he said. “We can do both later.” He watched me the way municipal people watch everyone, like we are all moving parts he would prefer not to replace. “There’ll be a hearing. He’ll be there. He’s good at making the word freedom sound like a novelty you haven’t tried yet and public health sound like a prude.”

“I’ll bring soup and a metaphor,” I said, and he winced because he knows the weaponized metaphor is basically how I set tables.

The hearing was scheduled in that room at City Hall with the chairs that have known sleeping people. The agenda wore a suit. There were names of companies that wanted the town to look like television and the names of clubs that wanted the town to keep its practice of badminton and grief. Auntie Bellflower didn’t come, because she doesn’t do meetings with recording devices unless she wants to be immortalized saying something about ditches that will make engineers blush for a century. An uncle was there in the back corner with the union jackets and the smell of coffee that has been boiled twice. A girl I know from the pond sat with a binder labeled “Everything at Once” and her hair in a braid like a rope she could climb up if someone pulled the room out from under her.

Brill took a seat only when the camera had found one for him that would make his left side do that charming thing with his bone, and he put his phone on the table face up so we could all see that he was not checking his face. He wore a shirt so ordinary it felt like a disguise he couldn’t quite carry off. When it was his turn to speak, he stood without using his hands, which is a neat trick that impresses audiences even if they don’t know why. He talked about joy and risk as if they were vitamins, and he talked about danger as if it were jazz, and he said the word censorship in a way that made three people in row two sit up and change their minds twice.

I waited. I stacked our muffins on a napkin and handed them down the row like contraband and community and watched at least two hearts soften enough to let a good argument in. When I spoke, I did not say his name because I am trying to teach myself that litanies are not binding contracts. I talked about laughter like a tool with settings, and about what we already do in this town when we put our mouths on the same moment. I told a story about a night when a brass band let a boy with grief in his elbows blow the air out of his lungs through their mouthpieces so his chest wouldn’t crack. I talked about tea as infrastructure, and I made a case for quiet corners as emergency exits for souls and not for bodies, and I watched the chair of the meeting un-cross and re-cross her legs when she realized this could be a clause she could be proud of on her re-election brochure.

Brill listened like a man taking notes in chalk on a wall that would wash in the rain. He flicked his gaze to the lens and back to me and put his hands together once, quietly, because he is not immune to an argument made well even if it is against what keeps his lights on. Hardeep’s clause passed in the way most good things in a city pass: not because it was moving but because it was administratively easier than arguing for another hour in chairs built to break your resolve. We all applauded without standing; the town learned a new trick and we saved our knees.

We came out into a midday that looked like it could go either way. At the corner by the bakery the influencer inevitability had arrived. He had a ring light like a halo and sneakers that had never touched mud, and his mouth was so soft it could only be maintained by someone making apologies for it on rotation. He had bait for kittens—flaky fish and the sound of the internet—and he had a following like a school of fish that did not know the ocean from a tank. He had already coaxed four cats into sitting on his lap for the kind of love that gets counted. People had gathered because humans do when there is a lens and a promise that someone will be humiliated by the end.

The kittens smelled the trap and didn’t mind, which is a cat’s worst habit and sometimes mine. Kids squealed and adults arranged their faces into delight because the camera demanded they behave like hometowns on postcards. Then one of the cats tried to cross the street because love and attention are separate moods and the city is a mouth you can fall into in an instant. I set the bowl on the curb and the key against the lip and the chalk along the gutter, and I could feel the math of the road’s cruelty starting to sum. Hardeep was there because he is there when you need a person with a vest and a plausible authority, and he stepped into the traffic with the posture of a yield sign. Mr. Li began to speak in the voice he uses for children who are behaving like floods, and somehow it reached everyone without being a shout. Layla made a human chain with three teenage boys who were bored until the work made them awake. The influencer kept filming like a man on a surfboard that has forgotten the ocean underneath.

I pulled the copper loop out and let it lie on the asphalt like a coin under glass. It isn’t magic exactly; it just suggests. It suggested to the cars that the corner was a loop and the drivers could not help seeing the space as round, not cutting it into parabolas with their urgency. The kittens came to the edge of that circle and sat because circles make sense to them. The children learned in a second what you teach over a summer in other places: how to stand with your knees soft, how to be a gate not a wall, how to send something small into safety without making it feel hunted. The influencer looked around for a villain and landed on me and did that thing with a jaw that says he has been told his anger is pretty. He said, into the stream, “Fairy tries to steal my content,” which is the kind of sentence that makes me want to replace all words with porridge and let the town figure itself out without grammar for a year.

“Your content,” I said, patient as kitchen tile. “These are citizens. This is not a zoo. This is a corner with cars and we would like it to stay a corner with cars and not blood. You can film from there if you also hold this,” and I put a sign into his hands that Layla had conjured from thin air that read: ask before filming; ask before petting; ask before asking. He held it the way men hold their daughters’ barrettes, like it would burn him, and then a double decker bus of embarrassment drove over his face at the exact speed it needed to, and he held it like a man told to carry his own groceries for once and discovering he had arms.

A woman in a scrubs top and office shoes stepped forward and put the smallest kitten in the crook of her arm where, under a hundred cameras, it began to fall asleep because it had found a heartbeat it could trust, and I made a decision I had been avoiding: not to bend the man who had trapped them into softness myself. I had wanted to. I had wanted to take his chin and tilt it until he felt foolish without me forcing him. I did nothing. I put my palm flat against the influence and told it: matte, and it turned itself down a notch and kept moving and it was enough.

Later, when we thought the danger was over, a boy with a backpack that had a logo that made me suspect he had money and not the training to handle it walked away with a carrier that looked like it had potatoes in it and had three cats instead. He had the look of someone who does not yet know the difference between collecting and saving. I had to follow him because small lives were inside his cardboard morals and it was not the town’s job to teach him on the street. Down a side lane that smelled like onions and betrayal, I called his name without knowing it and he turned because shock breaks the anonymities we layer over ourselves.

“Open it,” I said, a softness that would dent anyone. “Please.” He shook his head and the hair in his eyes made him younger than his arrogance would allow. “I need the content,” he said, and I thought of the day I had decided to make a habit of kindness and remembered that acquiring anything this way is a theft even if it makes you famous. I took the whisker key out and did something I had never tried in public in this register: I touched it to the idea of the latch. The box understood, which is to say it ceased to pretend to be stronger than my decision. The flap came up in his hands and the kittens looked at me with that expression that means I am here because you said hello and the world answered with light.

“Keep the box,” I said, because you always have to give a boy something to walk away with. “Put your headphones in it. Put an orange cat plush in it and learn to say no to the part of your brain that wants live things to make you feel more real. If you come to story night, I’ll give you the microphone for five minutes and you can say the truest thing you have, and then you can hold a kitten like a human and there will be no cameras on and it will be better.” He flushed and tried to make it look like anger and then like scorn and then like permission and finally he stumbled into grace. He left the box and its particular music of claws and cardboard on the ground and ran like a boy who has discovered his legs work.

Brill escalated the way he does when spectacle fails: he got quiet. Phones began to vibrate at the same minute like birds coming out of a bush. The notifications were all in the exact same tone, that little adorable trill that tells you a friend has liked you into being for one more day. “lol?” they said, in that punctuationless way that lets you put the guilt in if you want to, lets you put the venom in if you want to, lets you put your spare time into someone else’s pocket without knowing what you have bought. People looked down at their hands as if their hands had betrayed them, and the air went tight and thin.

Layla is a librarian and therefore a general, and she did not wait for my plan or for anyone’s permission. She had stocked the desk with stickers for summer reading that said DO NOT DISTURB ME I AM BUSY BECOMING and she began to pass them out to anyone who walked by and any screen she could reach. The camera boy, whose face is an open door more days than it should be, went up to the second floor of the mall and unplugged the thing that was shiny and loud and told people he was doing a test, and the supervisors let him because they are human and bored. Hardeep sent round an email that said the city was running a quiet hour as part of its new Tea Clause awareness and if employees wanted to participate they could, and ten percent did and twenty percent pretended and thirty percent wished they had, and that is a start.

I walked the thin places with the whisker key rattling like a coin in a prayer jar. At the router in the back hall I told the fans to hum like humble things. On the corner where the bus always arrives a little late I chalked a line and said on this side put your phone down. At the laundromat where the gossip spins faster than the machines, I put the copper loop on the counter and asked the woman whose kingdom this is to keep the volume of the world at neighbor and not at television. At the pond the fishermen sat and nodded like they had heard DMs hum in their pockets and had decided to be men whose attention could not be bought by dopamine in a sweater.

By evening, the town had succeeded at being less interesting than an appetite. Brill texted me a period. It was the most honest he has been all week. I sent back a comma, because I am rude and also because I am kind; the night needs a rest now and then.

The friend I had softened found me because tricks have a half-life and so do apologies. She had hair cut blunt and a jacket that says I have lived through weather. We went to the patch behind the band shell and sat on the short wall because chairs make speeches and stone makes confessions, and she told me with precision what I had taken from her the day I turned her into what she was not for the convenience of my conscience. She put her hands on her knees and kept her voice inside the legal limit and it still cut and I did not bandage it with jokes or with kittens or with the lie that I did not know what I had been doing when I did it. She said the word forgive without making a sentence out of it and I put my mouth around no, not yet, and she nodded because she does not owe me her smooth.

“What do you want when it happens again,” I asked, because this is what I can learn and it is the only thing that will make me less of a hazard to the people I love. She looked at the bench where sleeps happen and anger also and said, “Ask me first. Stand next to me, not in front. If you must, make me sharp, not soft. Remind me where to put the edge so that it cuts the cord I want cut and not my own fingers.” I gave her the copper loop because there are things that handle lightning better than flesh, and she put it around her wrist like a decoration and a safety and we walked home as if we were friends and not a fairy and her error.

A notice went up on the corkboard the next day with craft-knife precision and cheap staples that bite: KINDNESS PAGEANT: JUDGES ON SITE, PRIZES FOR SMALL ACTS, and my throat closed around the words until they tasted like irony. You cannot rate tenderness without making it into a weapon. You cannot rank kindness without teaching an audience to expect kindness like room service. He had scheduled it for the plaza by the skating rink where teenagers learn physics via bruises in winter and grandparents teach toddlers how to be pleased by small circles in summer. He had booked a pair of celebrities whose faces made people pay attention and whose souls I hoped were anywhere else. He had put out a call for nominations, which is to say he asked people to tattle on their own goodness and on other people’s debts.

I saw what he wanted: he wanted to make us tired of ourselves. We had been practicing the art of being decent in public for days, and it is exhausting if you don’t feed it right. He wanted to turn our habit into theatre and our theatre into content and our content into a reason to be cruel again because we were sick of our halo. I do not have enough power to cancel a spectacle. I have enough to reroute one so that when the current arrives it is ready to do something other than shock.

I made the hardest choice I have had to make since I walked out onto the lake and played chicken with the habits of water. I decided to withhold. I told the aunties and uncles and the cats and, worse, myself: for three days there will be no kittening at all, not even the small acts that make a teenager stop from pushing someone into a fountain or a man stop from telling a joke that will ruin a woman’s day.
