I said it as a vow into the bowl and the bowl was not pleased. It is like telling your spoon that you will not stir. It is like telling your lungs you will hold your breath while the town learns. It felt like cruelty and discipline and I hated myself for it and made soup so that my hands learned again that some labor is boring on purpose.

The first day people looked around for the trick and, not finding it, put their shoulders up and their eyebrows down; they bristled and did not bite. The second day was worse, because everyone had gotten used to the idea that softness would arrive when they were stupid and save their day for them like a coat someone else put over their shoulders in rain without asking. The third day the town remembered it had its own tools. Hardeep moved stanchions not to separate but to demonstrate correct distance, and people learned to mirror it without feeling corralled. Layla made a sign that said TAKE THE MICROPHONE BEFORE YOU REGRET NOT DOING SO and nine women used it in the first hour and each of them did not need me, which is the sentence that keeps me awake and lets me sleep. Mr. Li taught a child to dump an entire argument into a thermos and shake it and pour it out as tea and then decide whether to drink it; the metaphor did what metaphors do when they are fed and went home with that family to be used at a kitchen table until it became both joke and law.

The pageant tried to make kindness a costume and the town wore sensible shoes. Men with clipboards asked for nomination forms and were handed recipes and babysitting lists and the name of a locksmith who undercharges single mothers. The celebrity judges stood on a stage like saints at a parade and realized they were in a town that had learned not to treat them as altars. Brill saw it. He is vain and he is not stupid. He watched my quiet, and he watched how quickly the town learned that my quiet was not punishment but pedagogy, and it made him angry with the ferocity of a man who has discovered that someone else gets to be the season for a while. He took the microphone and made a joke about bureaucrats with tea kettles that should have landed like a clap and landed like a dropped spoon. He said, “Where is our fairy,” and people did not look at me because I had chosen a place to stand in the exact center of the crowd and be uninteresting. He asked me quietly, almost kindly, in the space between a child reciting her best thing—I returned my neighbor’s Tupperware, I washed it first—and a teenager telling us the worst thing—when my friend lied about me I wanted to die and then I wanted her to—and I shook my head with the mirror in my pocket so that the no could ring inside me and not bruise anyone.

The pageant ended with a brass band doing something complicated with a song that didn’t deserve it, and with the celebrity judges putting their faces on the tea clause and making a small video about civic kindness that might, ironically and finally, do some good. People went home with an aftertaste of labor and not of performance. The kittens came back the day after my vow ended, which is to say they had stayed away without sulking, which is a grace I did not think I would ever be able to ask of anything. They came with a look like inspectors and rubbed against the ankles of men who had been brave without wanting to be and women who had been honest with strangers and children who had left their phones face down for an hour because the stickers told them it might make them into humans. I poured milk into the bowl with a relief that made my hands shake and then steady.

That night I dreamt that the city had grown fur inside its walls and purred when we did something that would have made a worse town hiss. I dreamt of Brill with a bowl and of him drinking and not choking and of him, for once, not performing his swallow. I woke to the sound of a municipal truck breathing outside and my landlord’s cat trying to tell me that the water notice had become a filming notice again and that our block was about to be asked to perform being itself. The whisker key hummed in a key I had not heard before, a minor thing with teeth in it, and the burr on my sill had caught a spider that was more geometry than aggression and had built a net that would not catch anything except relief. I made coffee and put the bill back in my mouth and found it smaller again, like a coin you thumb when you need to remember that money exists but is not a god.

By lunch, the clip of me saying soup had become a meme and a local deli had put up a chalkboard that read TODAY’S SOUP: BRAVE LAUGHTER, and then in smaller chalk under it: we’re working on the recipe, please be patient. The used bookshop sign had finally laid down and let its pieces be letters on the sidewalk, and a kid knelt and turned them like puzzle tiles into YOU OAKS SEE US, and he laughed like he had invented something. The town had put its paws on the inside and learned to be gentle without my hands on its head, and I will be paying for that quiet for a while with attention and with showing up, and it is the best debt I have ever let climb onto my back and ride. In the evening I walked to the bridge that only teenagers call a bridge and I held the mirror up to my own mouth again and said yes, just once, quietly, to the part of me that wants to be adored without labor, and then I said no, out loud, to the man hiding under the shadow of the walkway with a camera who thought he would catch me being sentimental. He lowered it, and I lowered the mirror, and the night came down like weather that can be handled if you have a coat and a friend and a thermos, and lucky me, I had all three.

On the night the fireworks came early and the summer heat made the storm drains breathe, I walked along Yonge Street with pebbles in my shoes and moth dust on my shoulders. The traffic lights blinked their human semaphore; the jack pines whispered in a language that is older than any suburb. The sign for the used bookshop clicked, its O intermittently alive, so that it was U SED B OKS and then U SED BO KS and, briefly, US EDBOOKS—like a spell trying to remember itself.

I am a fairy. Not the kind that rustles out of graveyard stones with a harp and a tragic smile. I’m the kind that learned to put quarters in parking meters and hold a door open at the dentist’s because the hygienist was clearly overloaded. My ring—the circle that raised me, that I slip back into when the grass glows and the sounds of the highway soften—is behind a backyard fence in Richmond Hill, looks like trampled clover, and if you step into it without knowing to ask, it will borrow your name until you are clever enough to ask it back.

My name is Tamsin Reed. There have been other names. The one the railway line calls me is Silver Current. The one the raccoons call me cannot be translated without scraping up the throat. The one that matters tonight is the one my landlord spells wrong on the buzzer: Tamson.

He did it on purpose—another layer of misdirection; I don’t mind.

I came out because of a feeling. The air had a cindery taste, laughter had gone metallic at the edges. Somewhere, too near for comfort, a bad joke was growing teeth.

He always arrives like that: a prickle, as if the city’s neon nervous system were about to sneeze. First the laughter, then the hush, then the laughter again but with a warpy, barbed hook in it. I followed the sound past the bakery that stays open too late, past the bus shelter that catches more rain than it keeps off, to the patio of The Finch, where the umbrellas are all branded with a beer named after a province I have never put my feet in.

The Finch is not named for him, but it might as well be. Brill Grackle leaned against the rail like someone who had invented leaning. He is a fairy like me, but as a violin is like a hacksaw. Slung in denim, slick-smiled, eyes the color of that oily puddle sheen that makes children go oh. He was telling a story, and his hands—their gestures—were dangerous.

He tells jokes. He tells the kind that trip minds. In the old days he whispered into the ears of kings and dukes and shirtless shepherds, harmless now, you'd think, in a town with a good library and a bus schedule that sometimes works. Except you can do damage with jokes. He knows where the seams are.

“…and then she says—” Brill broke off because he saw me. His grin went knife-sharp and then softened into something like affection. “Tammy-Tam,” he said, welcoming, warning.

“Tamsin,” I said. “Nobody asked for you.”

“But they did,” he said, spreading his hands at his audience: a chemistry teacher, a man with a briefcase who pretended not to be listening, a cluster of young men drunk on being young and cheap IPA. “They asked with their boredom. I’m the answer to that, darling. And I brought new material.”

He had new material every time. He never told the same joke twice; he never had to. He could look at a scar and build a punchline around it, a punchline that opened like a hinge into whatever the person didn’t want to show. And tonight he was performing for the patio but also for me. He kept throwing me those sideways glances, those if-you’re-so-good-come-stop-me looks.

I could have. I have a knack that isn’t fair; it isn’t anything. It’s just what I am: I can turn anybody into a kitten.

I have turned a judge into a kitten once, for twenty-seven minutes; he was heavenly soft and so very small, and he purred in a frequency that I still hear when I am too tired to sleep. I turned a bus driver into a kitten when he was about to punch another bus driver for calling his mother a rude noun; they both wrestled gently on the seat while I drove their route, which yes, was excessive, but no one got hurt, and the passengers were very patient when I missed Steeles and had to double back. I turned my landlord into a kitten for exactly one breath when he said I was a month late on rent and I wasn’t. He apologized for the error and we pretended not to notice the yellow fur on his shoulder.

I could have turned Brill into a kitten. I didn’t, because he would not have stayed kitten-shaped; he would have clawed his way out of the spell and also because I am not supposed to use that on our own kind. There is Law. It is slippery and moss-edged, but it is real, and I keep it when I can.

He started again. His voice is a good voice, I’ll give him that. He spoke softly so people leaned in. The punchline came like a goose walking on ice. There was laughter, that was laughter, then there were faces turning into gates—open, too open, nothing behind the eyes. He had pushed the joke too far and they had followed him. He went further. The joke got... worse. Not violent. Not illegal. Not something I’ll repeat.

A girl in a red shirt put her hand over her mouth and was laughing and crying at the same time. The chemistry teacher’s cheeks burned. Someone dropped a glass. Brill’s teeth flashed.

“Enough,” I said.

“Tamsin,” he crooned, not looking at me. “Don’t be dull.”

“I understand why you don’t talk to our aunties anymore,” I said. “But do you understand how thin this is? The skin between world and hey-whoops? Stop it.”

He tapped the rail with his knuckles, tat-tat-tat, and told one more line. His laughter found the bit of you that thinks you are a worse person than you present and pressed on it. People laughed as if they were apologizing to the air.

The girl in red stood. Her chair scraped. One of the beer-blooming young men reached to tug the edge of her shirt like he didn’t have a mother. I sighed. I felt the familiar rush in my fingers.

Kitten.

The young man blinked. His hands were suddenly soft-padded, his expression a perfect small question. He sat. His friends made seals of themselves, flapping and hooting. The girl stared, then scooped him—no, him, not a cat, never a cat entirely—into her arms by instinct and said what you say to a sudden kitten: “Oh my God.” She stroked behind his ears. He went boneless with simple bliss, the joke dropping out of him like a nail from rotten wood.

“Dirty pool,” Brill murmured. “You always did prefer soft answers.”

“You always did like hard ones,” I said. I walked onto the patio and without touching anyone touched their attention. “Hey,” I said, lightly. “This is a funny fairy, he tells jokes, but he sometimes forgets to bring consent to the table. Laugh if you want to. Don’t if you don’t. This is me pressing the reset button. Ha-ha.”

The air wobbled and bumped back into alignment. Someone coughed. The man with the briefcase stared at me and then at the kitten, which I was not going to let remain a kitten for more than a minute because there’s an ethical calculus to this that I am not terrible at. Still, I did my terrible little trick again. Softened him. Kittened a second boy who was winding up to say something you can’t say. He shrank; his anger shrank with him.

Brill’s smile did a slow handstand, then righted itself. “Oh, Tamson,” he said, deliberately, a needle in it. “From the Hill. Loves her little cats. Does tricks. Fetches slippers and brings them to the party.”

That wasn’t a joke, really. That was a brute fact disguised as insult. I have always lived here, or always enough. The old rings knew me; the new restaurants did, too. I was one of those fairies that stayed when the others bored themselves back into lakes and cigarette smoke. It gives a person a reputation.

“Go home,” I told him, and felt the brushing, like crows feathering over my scalp, of other eyes. Our aunties look at us when we do things. Our uncles don't look but listen. There are not so many of us that we can afford to ignore each other.

He took a breath. He could have dug in—turned mean, turned nasty, turned the whole patio into a chorus of sheepish cruelty. He didn’t. He tipped two fingers like a hat. “Later,” he said. “You’ll wish you’d come to listen.”

“Unlikely,” I said.

He hopped the railing like gravity was a suggestion and strolled north into slick blue. The sound of his footfalls was like someone synching a metronome to your heartbeat and then wobbling it off.

The young men turned back at the same time to being men. One—kitten number one—scruffed the back of his neck, bleated a laugh, tried for embarrassment like it was a jacket he hadn’t worn in a while. “What was that,” he said.

“You were rude,” the girl in red said, excellent, crisp. She fixed him with a look that someday will level buildings. “She saved you from being worse. Say thank you.”

He looked at me. “Thanks,” he muttered. “Sorry, I think.”

“It’s fine,” I said. “It’s summer. The moon makes fools of everybody.” I don’t think that’s true, but it sounded right. I paid the bar back for the broken glass, which was a coin each to the two students washing dishes in the back, because it isn’t the same as paying, but it covers some things money can’t.

When I step back out onto the sidewalk, the world resumed its rich, complicated hum. A bus coughed. A bicycle whispered past like a long-limbed insect, bells half-hearted as a yawn. Someone’s radio played a song from before I was born that I know the chords to—because there are only so many chords and we arrange them in endless ways.

Layla was waiting under the birch just beyond the sushi place. She raised both eyebrows at me, and her shoulders read: So? and Well? Layla knows my business. She is human with a capital H and a minor in Secrets. I met her when she was fourteen and talked to the squirrels because her house was noisy with other people’s arguments; she is twenty-seven now and runs the children’s section at the library as if it were a frontier post in a war against blandness.

“You care too much,” she said. It wasn’t unkind.

“I care as much as it takes,” I said. “He was here.”

“I figured,” she said. “A kid came in earlier and tried to check out a book we don’t carry by making a joke. It kind of worked? I found a copy of it in the storage closet. Not normal.”

“Clever boy,” I said. Brill can make desire heavy enough to pull things into your hands. Not conjuring, exactly, just a sleight that shimmies the shelves. “Don’t let him work the early readers into learning rude words.”

She smiled, a quick glint. “I won’t,” she said. She put her hand on my sleeve. “You okay?”

“I’m annoyed,” I said. “He keeps coming closer. Like he’s testing the fence.”

“There is no fence,” Layla said. “Not for him.”

Fair. He had never respected lines. But there are other kinds of fences. Geography. Ritual. The rhythms that become familiar and guard as much as they bind. Richmond Hill is something like a lullaby to me: the way the sky opens over the plazas, the water hum from Mill Pond, the chatter around the soccer fields where the kids are better than they think. All of that is a net that keeps me from falling.

We walked south together. Layla’s keychain chimed. The sky was a heat-bruise. “He’s planning something,” I said. “I can feel it the way you can feel that the streetlights are about to buzz on.”

“When?” she said.

“Midsummer,” I said. “At the parade, probably.”

She made a face. “That’s three nights away. Will he wait?”

“He’ll pretend to,” I said. “He’ll poke between now and then to see where it itches.”

She said: “So shampoo the city?”

I laughed. “I’ll do what I can.”

We walked. The world felt tipped, like a cup about to spill. Somewhere a spoon fell. The wind had fallen asleep and the maples were waiting for the night to comb their hair.

I took Layla home. Her apartment above the tailor smells like wool steam and old books. On her fridge, magnets shaped like punctuation marks are arranged so that it reads, by accident or design: ! ! ? and I approve. She put on a kettle and I sat in her chair by the window and listened to the building talk to itself through the pipes.

“You could ask the aunties to help,” she said at last.

“And what would they say?” I asked.

“Don’t be personal,” she said. “Ask. They might say yes.”

“They might take over,” I said. “They might say stop being kind.”

“Kindness isn’t your weakness,” she said, gently.

“It’s a habit, though,” I said. “Habits and weaknesses look the same at a distance.”

We drank tea. We told each other gently ridiculous stories from the day—two kids pretending the stacks were caves, Mr. Li the retired astronomer holding court at the park bench describing comet tails as if he had combed them himself, the family at the bus stop speaking three languages and laughing in a fourth. The small, steady good things are a kind of magic that doesn’t show up in any of our books. But they build the floor you fight on.

After midnight I went home. The mosquitoes wanted me, but I am inedible when I’m annoyed. My building is brick that thinks it's a tree: it picks up squirrels and keeps them, it drops leaves in the hallways sometimes. On the second landing my landlord’s cat, who is not my doing, eyed me with deep suspicion for reasons of her own. My door stuck in the summer. I sang it open.

Inside, my apartment exhaled, same as me. There is a rug. There are the old postcards I send myself when I leave and return every time, to make coming and going a game rather than an ache. There is the shelf that holds the whisker key.

The whisker key is exactly what it sounds like: a key, made of six whiskers braided, lacquered with something that is not sap and not resin, handles a little cold, teeth sharp as noon. It opens things that are too stubborn for any other tool. I once saw it open the idea of a door. The aunties gifted it to me when I bound my trick, when I declared what I was, when I became—reluctantly and maybe forever—The One With The Kittens. It was important to have a tool that wasn’t one trick only. They have their moods, those aunties. Sometimes they hand you a skein of shadow and say here, knit. Sometimes they hand you a whisker key and it saves your life.

I took it down and held it. It hummed like a tuning fork. It was either ready or simply alive. I put it in my bag.

I also packed: three chalks (white, coral, and twilight), a loop of copper wire, the length of thread I had pulled from my own dress when I saved a boy in winter from turning himself into a story, two pennies, a piece of frit glass from a church window, a bow I did not know how to use (hopeful, I guess), and a cat toy shaped like a sardine that some part of me considered a talisman. I left the houseplants a note: Back soon. Water yourselves judiciously. –T.

Sleep would not come. I listened to the slow tick of someone else’s clock through a wall. I thought of Brill’s voice cutting into rooms and making them laugh despite themselves. He calls that freedom. He is wrong, but he believes it, and that makes him fearless. I thought of all the ways a joke works like a spell and all the ways it doesn’t. A joke, it turns out, is a ladder: you climb it and then throw it away. He builds ladders over places we have put a lot of effort into not falling.

When dawn came on a moth wing, I put my face in the frost of the freezer and breathed in cold air until my thoughts stopped shimmering. Then I went to see Auntie Bellflower.

You find Auntie Bellflower by not looking for her. The backyard is a backyard, the fence a fence. The mulberry tree leans, and there is a swing, and there is a patch of wrong clover that makes the light taste sweet. You knock on the fence twice, then twice again, then once. The fence opens an eye. If it likes you, it winks. If it doesn’t, it tells you a story and you forget your name for an hour. I am liked, which is not the same thing as being welcome, but suffices.

Inside the ring, everything is taller. The grass reaches my knees. The dandelions exchange straws. The wind speaks with etiquette. Auntie Bellflower sat on a mushroom that had never known a boot, plucking a harp made of minute bones. Her hair was the color of words you aren’t supposed to say to your grandmother. She looked up.

“Well, if it isn’t Tamsin,” she said. “If it isn’t Richmond Hill’s civil servant without a salary.”

“You say that as if it were a profession,” I said.

“It is,” she said. “We used to call it being harmless. We used to call it doing no harm. We used to be worse at it than you are.” She cocked her head. “You smell like engine noise and bad timing. What did he do?”

“He told jokes,” I said.

“Ah,” she said. “That’s his only trick and his sharpest spear. Your trick is softer but it leaves marks too.”

“I know,” I said. “I make choices.”

“You always did,” she said. She put the harp down on her lap. “Brill is playing with you. It is not that he doesn’t have other projects; he always has other. But you are a string he can pluck and get a note that pleases him. You two have this way.”

“We are not a we,” I said too fast.

“You are an opposition,” she said. “That is a kind of we.”

“He’s going to use Midsummer,” I said. “He wants a spectacle. He’ll take the parade and stretch it until it breaks.”

“He will try to sing shame into chorus,” Auntie Bellflower said. “He is very good at it. He always has been.”

“Help me,” I said. “Don’t stop me. Just help me a little.”

She looked past me into the ring’s brighter place, the place with the whistlelines and spider-cranes raising webs like bridges. “I have so many nieces and nephews,” she said. “You think I can make choices for all of you? I am not a manager, Tamsin. I am not a god.”

“You’re better than both,” I said. “And anyway, you love me best.”

She laughed, a slanting sound that tasted of honey and burnt sugar, which is to say complicated. “Bring your whisker key,” she said. “Bring your copper and your chalk. Bring a mirror you can see yourself in even when you’re not looking, and a bowl of milk.”

“Milk,” I said. “Auntie, that is a cliché.”

“And yet,” she said, all gravity. “You always get stuck on the parts of the old stuff that are silly. Sometimes the silly parts are the bones. Milk. Enough for a kitten, you understand? There will be one. Maybe a thousand. Who can say.”

I hated her for being right and being vague. “And a mirror?”

“Hold a joke in front of a mirror and watch it flinch,” she said. “He will hate that.”

“He’ll break it,” I said.

“Then he’ll get seven years of some kind of trouble,” she said calmly. “It has to be that way for someone. Better for him than for you.”

The sun moved in a way suns do not for humans and I stood, my legs full of pins and needles because time here prickles. “Will you stand with me?” I asked, too quickly. Too small.

She looked at me with the soft part of her eyes, the side that sometimes still remembers my baby face and the way I would stare at the ceiling fan and clap as if it were a clock. “No,” she said. “I cannot. I shouldn’t. This is your fight. It is your patch. He chose your stage.”

I nodded. I left the ring, which closed behind me like a mouth over a peach. The mulberry leaves said some very inappropriate things to me as I went; I pretended not to hear.

The city was happening. It always is. Moms carted strollers as if they were little ships in high wind. The joggers did their self-flagellating thing. The dog people met the other dog people, telegraphing complicated messages with leash hand gestures and scoops. I went to Mr. Li’s and told him his tomatoes were about to be ambushed by hornworms and told the hornworms to try the basil instead, and then I felt him. Again, already.

This time he had found the schoolyard where the fence is missing three slats and the shade sits at the perfect angle for the bench. He had a small crowd: two teens with shaved kewpie curls, a woman who wore her grief like a jaguar on a leash, the man who sells phone plans in the kiosk and sells jokes if you press him. Brill balanced on the top rail of the fence, examining his nails, and every so often he spoke and the crowd rippled.

“Brill,” I said.

“Tamsin,” he said, bored. “I am trying quieter material. Intimate stuff.” He stretched his legs as if to show that he could, and wasn’t that a wonder.

“Whisper it into your coat,” I said.

“You don’t own silence,” he said. “No one does.”

“Silence is rented like everything else,” I said. “You pay for it with attention. And you, sir, never pay.”

“Where would you like me to begin? The list of my vices? The case for my defense?” He hopped down. “You muzzled me last night. That wasn’t bad. The boys purring on their friends’ laps. Good television. But I have to say—”

“Don’t,” I said, because what came next would be lewd and it would hurt someone who didn’t come here to be hurt. He said it anyway. A clean, brutal line. The woman with the jaguar-grief laughed, then bit her tongue so hard I think it bled. Brill watched her as if she were an experiment.

“Enough,” I said, again.

“Always,” he said, wide-eyed. “It is always that with you. Enough. As if the world had an ideal gentle median where people keep hands to themselves and their thoughts sifted like flour and their mouths sweet with the little lies that keep an afternoon from tearing. I love you for it. I do. It’s not for me.”

“I don’t need you to be like me,” I said. “I need you to not pull people into your current without a lifejacket.”

“I am a lifejacket,” he said. “Sometimes I pull them out of waters you don’t see. They find out things and laugh until they get air back. That’s what a joke is. That’s what I am.”

I reached and drew a line with chalk between his shoes. “Here,” I said. “Perform this way. Away from them.”

He looked down at the chalk line and then looked up, and I realized he had wanted me to make a move that would let him move more. He stepped back deliberately over my line and told a small story about a busker, a cop, and a bouquet of gerberas, and the story clicked with the exact wrong part of the woman with jaguar-grief. She went still. Not calm. Not ready. Still like a mouse when the shadow passes overhead.

I sighed that sigh. Even my sighs have muscle memory. Kitten. He’d picked his audience well; there were no men itching for an excuse to be kittens. The two teens shrank and softened and looked surprised at their tails; the woman tipped her head at me, not a kitten, not even close. Not everyone can be, thank the greens. She looked at me as if a rope had loosened around her shoulders exactly one notch, and then she looked at Brill as if he were a bruise she would not be pressing again soon.

“Don’t,” I said to him. “Midsummer is coming. Don’t make me fight you with an entire town watching.”

“Don’t pretend you wouldn’t love it,” he said, and that is the part where he was wrong. I like a private victory. I like quiet. I like the feeling of being the human variation while the loud things shake out their noise elsewhere. “Bring your milk and your mirror,” he said, and this time it was like he’d been listening to the fences, too. He knows almost everything that isn't his.

“You first,” I said.

He tipped his head at the teens, who were batting a bee back and forth with very round paws and tiny, murderous intent. He tipped his head at me. He tipped off the fence again and went, a breeze with a knife taped under its coat.

Layla texted: Meeting in 20? I wrote back: Soon. Be careful.

I brought milk home. Not for me. I am not that kind of fairy, not anymore. It is a ritual. Objects ask to be used the way they are meant to be; deny them that and you make a tangle. I poured the milk into a bowl so white it seemed to erase the counter under it, put the mirror on the kitchen table, a hand mirror with a fox engraved on the back that I stole and then paid for and then was permitted to keep by a woman who sees very clearly.

I practiced. You can practice being terse; you can practice not explaining yourself beyond the point that affects the work. I drew circles with chalk on paper so I could throw the paper away, not litter the world with circles that might become doors. I set the whisker key down in a patch of sun so it would purr. I spoke the words that were not words at all: the rising humming vowels of Please and Now and You Stop, the clipped consonants of No More.

I thought of kittens, their simple complete needs, their huge ridiculous paws. I thought of what I could do to Brill that wasn’t cruel. I thought of what it would be to turn him kitten-soft, just for a second, to give him the feeling of being cherished without edges, and whether that would teach him what he refuses to learn. He would claw out at once. He would hate me. He would be himself again, sharper for the sanding.

It got hot. The whole town steamed. People who owned air conditioning blessed their ancestors; the rest of us perspired modestly or immodestly and let the night come.

It came scented with barbecue and grass, the far-off ring of a baseball bat, laughter that did not claw. I went to the pond and the fishermen who fish for stories nodded like we shared a route. Mr. Li waved me over and handed me an ice. “The moon is late,” he said, as if that were up to it. “I think it’s trying another route.”

“Tell it to take Bathurst,” I said. “Less construction.”

We sat. The frogs tuned up. Between and under everything was a vibration like a joke waiting to happen, like a curtain waiting to go up. I do not love that feeling. It asks and asks. It is a mouth.

“Tell me,” Mr. Li said, and I told him the true part: that a fairy was bothering people in public, and that I was going to stop him in public. He nodded, like a man acknowledging a chess opening he’d seen before. “Bring witnesses,” he said. “Bring someone to laugh at the right place. It matters where laughter falls.”

“It does,” I said. “I’ll bring Layla. She knows the beats. She knows how to not feed him.”

“You can also,” he said.

“I can try,” I said.

We made arrangements without calling them that. The whole world is made of arrangements. You can walk through them like spiderwebs and pretend they aren’t there, but then your cheek stings and your hands get sticky.

Two days. The parade swelled in the winter plans and sprang up in summer wood and cloth. Kids decorated wagons and then reluctantly let adults help. A brass band that was mostly broken but had three trumpets showed up. Paper lanterns hung careful as croissants. Layla built a booth with a sign that read: Read Out Loud and raised a stack of stories as if they were sandbags. I chalked invisible lines here and there that would slow things if they had to slow, and built a net you wouldn’t notice, made of Yes You May and Please Step Aside and No Not You. The whisker key hummed in my pocket where I tucked it like a secret.

Brill sent messengers, as if we were in a play. A crow dropped a strip of paper that read: don’t wear yellow. A squirrel told me a filthy riddle that I will not repeat and got a cherry for his trouble. A cloud shaped like a mouth drizzled on me when I stood at the corner of Major Mackenzie and Yonge and three kids laughed and I laughed back, because weather has its own comedy.

On the morning of the thing, I rose early and fed the idea of courage with toast. I wore shoes I could run in. I left a note for the houseplants that said: forgive me. I tucked the mirror into its scarf and made the milk new and cold. I texted Layla: please be early, please bring your voice.

At the park, the day opened like a folding chair. People who had only ever been alone in their kitchens stood shoulder to shoulder and discovered they were friends. Auntie Bellflower didn’t come, because she said she wouldn’t, but there were others from the rings, disguised as the woman who sells kettle corn, as the old man napping under a hat, as the kid with a skateboarding T-shirt who never blinked. They were there because we are nosy. Also because we pretend not to be a community but we are. Also because our aunties do not do nothing; even when they do nothing they do it beautifully and with careful omissions.

Brill came late. He came like the last course of a meal you’re already full from but smell and think: oh, fine. He wore white, to spite the don’t wear yellow note, and his shirt had a stain on it shaped like a map of a country that needed better water management. He didn’t take a stage. He found an absence—between the band and the bouncy castle, at the open lip of the pond—and stepped into it as if he had paid for it.

People noticed the way grass notices feet. This is how it happens when he is strong: no horns, no spotlight. Attention tips toward him like it has been waiting to pour. He didn’t say his name. He didn’t ask us to gather round. He told a small, precise story about a dad who lost his temper and then apologized, and because he could not be patient he laced it with a barb and everyone felt the barb and laughed to prove it didn’t stick. It did. It always does. He went on.

I didn’t jump. I waited. I let him build his little rope bridge across the gorge. The thing with jokes is that they are navigation; they end where they mean to end. You must let them take you there. When he had brought the room—field, pond, strollers, brass—up to a simmer, when he had turned everyone into one animal with one breath, I stepped.

“Hi,” I said, not loudly. I poured the milk into the white bowl that belonged to my grandmother. The air discharged like a storm thinking better of itself. Brill’s eyes flicked to the bowl and then to the mirror and then to me. I had a moment to enjoy that.

“Kitty Queen,” he said.

“Bard of Bad Timing,” I said back, and saw several heads tilt at the word Bard like oh lovely.

He smiled. “You brought props.”

“You always do,” I said, and gestured at his mouth.

People found that funny. He did not.

“This is my town,” I said—to him and to everyone else. “You’re a guest here if you’re here at all. That means I get the right of reply. That means you do not get to say whatever you want and then pretend that ‘just joking’ is a spell that bleaches consequences. That means I will take your joke, and I will turn it around, and we will see what bites.”

He swayed. “You can’t reverse a joke,” he said. “You break it if you try. It isn’t a mirror. It’s an arrow.”

“It’s a boomerang,” I said, and held up the mirror so it caught him, so for one split second he saw his own shape about to speak. He flinched. He smiled as if that were part of the routine. He tried to talk into the mirror. His voice skipped. The edge fell off the syllables like a knife losing its serration. He tried again.

“Once,” he began, and I heard the shift in the crowd: the hunger to hear the story, the hope it would be nice and the resilience if it was not. I placed the mirror against my chest and leaned it so that it showed the bowl of milk and then Brill’s eyes. I took the whisker key out and set it delicately on the edge of the bowl. The sound it made was not a sound but everyone heard it in their teeth.

He blinked. “What are you doing,” he said, as if we had been sitting together with cups of tea and not knotted in a game that would call itself war if it had more honor.

“Interrupting,” I said. “Politely.”

“Rude,” he said, delighted, and then his delight hooked itself into the wrong angle because I let myself smile too. That cracked something between us. He saw what I would do and couldn’t help wanting to see it done.

“Say it,” I invited.

He said it. He said the first of his Midsummer lines, a tidy, cruel joke disguised as a kindness, with a parent at the center and a child at the edge and the sharp delight of doing wrong because someone says it’s right. As the words left his mouth I put my hand between them and him and turned my hand once, twice, as if unscrewing a lid from a jar. I heard it. You hear it when I do it: a mew as clear as a bell.

His voice fell soft and small. It didn’t stop being his voice, it just became gentle. He put his hand to his mouth, startled, and snatched it away as if he’d been caught doing something private. He glared at me. He loved me for a heartbeat. Hated me for three.

“You like humiliation,” he said, too low for anyone else.

“I like the truth with claws out,” I said. “Yours is not the only version.”

He tried again. He reached for a deeper cut. He began a story about a woman who wanted the wrong things. I held the mirror up so he had to look at himself as he said it. I didn’t make him a kitten because he would have broken my spell out of pure spite and bloodied himself on the edges. I did what Auntie said: I held the joke up to itself and watched it flinch.

He sneered, just a little. He stretched his nice mouth around the line that would have made twenty people here vulnerable, and he could not finish it. He huffed a laugh. “You’re no fun.”

“And yet,” I said. “Ask around. I’m the best fun.” I let the crowd laugh and some of them did, a real good laugh, not the kind he sells. Layla’s laugh, especially, rang pure, the laugh of someone who understands the structure of things and likes them anyway. Mr. Li put his hand over his heart and coughed, which is what he does when he places a check where he wants a checkmate to be.

Brill took one step back. One step forward. Pleasure ran across his face and left it like someone wiping crumbs off a plate. “We could do this forever,” he said.

“No,” I said, “we couldn’t,” and I pushed. Not him. The world.

There are lines you can draw between breaths. There are circles you can make around laughter. There are nets you can cast that catch intention instead of fish. I had laid them all this morning because I had seen how he moves, and I set one gently under him now, and when he tried for his next joke, he slipped and fell through to the floor of himself.

It was a soft fall. I am not cruel. He stood in the bowl of milk up to his ankles and hissed like a displeased cat and realized he was not going to die from that feeling. The crowd made a sound that people make when they see a magician mess up in a way that turns out to be the real trick, the benevolent inside-out of a show-off’s show.

“Come away,” I said, to him. “Come away with me and try kindness. Just once. Just to see if it’s the kind of chemical that changes you.”

He looked more dangerous at that invitation than he had all morning. He looked at my hand as if it were a snake that wanted to share its venom. “I won’t,” he said.

“You might,” I said.

He looked at the milk and sneered and stepped out, pristine. The milk had not so much as spattered his hem. He is good at not being touched. He is better at leaving you without noticing. He turned to the crowd and bowed. “You have been magnificent,” he said, and the sleaziest part of the day was that he meant it. “Tip your servers,” he added, and pointed at me.

“No,” I said, “tip the band,” and the whole line of brass laughed and took off at a tempo that broke the spell in ten strides. The strollers went back to being wheels and naps. The pond fish resumed their small politics. Layla stepped into Brill’s path and handed him a book.

“For you,” she said. “There’s a very funny ending.”

He took it. He is not stupid. He knows a curse when he smells one. He knows a gift that tastes the same as obligation. He tucked it under his arm and offered her a line that would have turned her eyebrows to frost; she stared him down and he let it fall. He melted away, the way he does, the way a joke does when it’s told in the wrong room.

I picked up the whisker key and the mirror and the bowl, and my hands were shaking just enough that I wanted to be a kitten—small, unaccountable, loved for making mischief in a way that breaks nothing. But I am Tamsin. I am supposed to walk home now, and I did, with Layla on my left and Mr. Li behind me measuring the length of a treeline with his hands because he was excited and he has his ways of saying so.

We didn’t win; not like that. You never do, against a creature like Brill, not fully and not forever. But there was a dent in him. A bruise where his joke had hit the mirror and bounced back. There was milk drying in the grass like an offering. There was the knowledge that laughter could be placed. It mattered where it fell. It mattered when we stepped in.

At my door, the key did the thing it does, turning the lock and also the words around it so that my name was safe inside. I set the mirror down and it reflected a ceiling that isn’t mine but is, and the bowl in the sink had a ring around it at the exact height of Brill’s ankles and somehow that pleased me like a recipe that came out edible when it shouldn’t have. The houseplants forgave me with great dignity. I left the whisker key on the windowsill where the light could lick it, and I sat down to write a note to Auntie that said: I did it, kind of. Thank you. And also: he is not finished.

The night asked for my hands and I gave them. The night asked for my voice and I told it yes and no and maybe in a pattern that is a kind of music. I slept. I dreamed of kittens, but also of foxes, and of white bowls that held everything I am willing to hold. In the morning, the radio said it might rain later. I said good. Let it. Let the whole town wash its face. Let us start again and again, every time.

The rain came like a forgiveness it hadn’t entirely earned, first a spit, then a sifting, then a proper wash. It took the skins off heat and laid them over the storm drains, which breathed like sleeping animals and then like bellows when the gutters filled. The city drank. The jack pines steamed. The sidewalks re-summarized themselves as if they were rewriting an essay they’d already handed in and gotten back with too many red marks. I walked without a destination because destinations feel like claims, and I was not ready to claim anything but already had too much to guard.

When a town washes its face, names rise like soap bubbles, and some of them pop. The used bookshop sign blinked in a sequence that made a different word altogether—U SED OB KS—like it had lost its breath laughing. A bus rolled past with the route panel saying OOPS because the rain had got to whatever innards made its letters, and five passengers smiled at the delirium and five scowled and one took a picture because that’s what we do when something lifts out of regular. The picture was already halfway around several phones by the time the bus took a corner, and if you think magic doesn’t use Wi-Fi when it can, you haven’t been paying attention.

Layla texted a series of rain emojis and also a soup bowl, which I chose to interpret as a call for pho. I told her I’d meet her later, after I had done my rounds, which is not a thing anyone told me to do but that I chose to do until it became a kind of job. I checked the park and the pond and the back of the bakery where the rats are elegant as thieves. I loosened a knot on a swing. I tightened a knot in a kid’s sneaker and made sure he thought he had done it himself. I looked at the fence with the three missing slats and put my face against the damp wood. The world on the other side smelled like mint crushed underfoot and something a little bitter, the kind of bitter that makes medicine work.

If Brill had left a trap, it would be in the laughter, so I listened to laughter. There was the laugh of the man who got splashed by a taxi and pretended to be a saint about it. There was the unsuppressed cackle of the teenager who stepped in the puddle on purpose because he wanted to feel like a child. There was the shy ripple of two people who had not known whether to go on a first date and had decided, fine, if the world is this wet, let’s swim. None of those were his. His laughter passed through people like a current, leaving them bright and scraped. The aftertaste wasn’t here. He had gone to ground or gone online, which in our age is the same thing with a different drainage system.

I stopped at the library because it is Layla’s church and my favorite kind of fortress. The children’s section sounded like it was radiating during a power surge, little voices pitched to a hum that interfered with the air. Layla stood behind her desk and gave me a look that was ninety percent knowing and ten percent I didn’t sleep enough. There were paper cranes on the string above her that had been birds in other hands and were now metastories. She jerked her chin toward the back room.

“He’s in the catalog, somehow,” she said, when the door closed and the smell of crayons took over from old glue. “I mean, not him-him. But he has a trick in there. Do you know the thing where you type three letters and it suggests a book you were embarrassed to check out last year because your ex gave it to you and you don’t want to admit you liked it? It’s that but worse.”

“He taught the library to remember what you thought you were over,” I said, and only then realized my nails were in my palms as if I could hold onto other people’s privacy for them through my skin.

“It’s adds-you-into-baskets energy,” Layla said. “Like you’re at the grocery and the cart sees what your neighbor is buying and decides you must want it too. It’s subtle. It’s sticky. I’m trying to not throw the server in the bathtub.”

“You say that as if you haven’t already done it in your mind,” I said, and she grinned briefly because she had, and because my guessing made her feel read and liked.

“I can scrub it, probably,” she said. “Or teach the system to laugh at him. That sometimes works. If a computer can pretend to be bored with a demon, the demon loses interest. They like vanity mirrors, not matte finishes.”

“Teach it to be matte,” I said. “I’ll walk the stacks.”

If you think walking stacks is nothing, you have never thought about spines whispering to each other about the hands that touched them. I followed a thread of not-funny into the 398s and then into the row where how-to manuals stand shoulder to shoulder with open secrets. A lime green tutorial on home repairs was emitting jokes about fathers that had never even tried to fix a leaky faucet, and my temper blipped so hard it sent a small flock of calm out to graze. I put my hand on the shelf and told it a story about the man I had watched at the park who fixed a stranger’s rolled stroller wheel and then cried into his sleeve because that was the last thing he had done for his daughter before she told him she was moving out, and laughter rose in the shelf like yeast, gentle and true. The mean line dissolved. I knew then where Brill had slipped in: in the place where we categorize human error and teach ourselves not to be tender about it.

At the circulation desk a woman returned a book with an apologetic smile that had a rictus built into it, and we all felt Brill’s finger under the corners of her mouth. “Overdue,” she said, and the word bristled, and Layla stepped forward like a conductor bringing in a string section and said, “No worries,” which is a phrase that I mistrust when it comes too easy, but she said it in a way that meant: I see you. It worked. The word overdue became about a book and not about a moral failing, and we moved on.

When I left the library the rain was thinking about stopping, which for rain is a complicated thought. It draped itself over the air and inspected its own drips like a seamstress checking a hem. My whisker key vibrated in my bag with the precise irritation of a small creature whose needs were not being met quickly enough. I took it out and held it, and the damp made it sound a little higher, like a violin someone had tuned for a smaller room. The key has interests. It finds doors, not just in walls but in people. It wants me to be brave and clever and also remembered, and it sulks when I am any of those without its help.

The first kitten found me at the corner of a puddle that thought it was a pond. It was not a conjuration. It was one of the city’s cats, half feral, all self, with a notch in its ear and eyes the shade of glass that becomes ocean when you love it too much. It looked at me as if it thought I had something to do with the weather, which is nice to be accused of on a morning like this. It sniffed at the cuff of my jeans and then at the key and then made the sound that in my head is the word Well?, which I have been told is an error, but I am allowed some. I put a finger under its chin and it agreed to be admired. We stood there in a miniature truce until an umbrella swished by and the cat went wherever cat business takes you when you don’t have pockets.

The ring behind the fence in Richmond Hill had swollen during the night. You could tell by the way the grass around it leaned in, and by the way the wrong clover looked righteous, and by the way the fence had a new eye that refused to wink. Auntie Bellflower wasn’t there. The air had the taste of someone else’s song. An uncle, then. They come when they think duty needs a cane.

He was sprawled on a log as if exhaustion were a mantle he had earned the right to wear, and he looked like the kind of man you would follow into a bar fight and discover you had signed up for a philosophy lecture instead. His hair had the texture of old bark. His eyes had the color of lakes right before thunder. He was not mine. He was married to a swampdream I had once touched by mistake and still had reeds in my teeth from.

“Child,” he said, with the confidence of people who have decided the words that name you should be like coats, one-size and unisex.

“Nephew,” I said back, because rank and files have their pleasures.

“Bellflower is mending something that needed to be mended,” he said, which meant someone had asked a river to do a road’s job again and she had gone to speak to the municipal planners and they had had polite tea and then she had broken a culvert with a look. “So I came to see what you were teaching the city about itself.”

“I am teaching it a trick called that wasn’t funny and it’s okay to say so,” I said.

He picked a burr out of his sleeve and rolled it between thumb and forefinger as if daring it to protest. “And you used a mirror on a boy who eats reflections,” he said. “I am not here to scold you. I am here to warn you of the bill.”

“I know there’s a bill,” I said. “I can feel it in my joints and in my hair. He will not forget being seen. He will make me feel seen in a way I do not want, and I will have to pay attention to that feeling without sending the city to bed at eight with no supper. Is there a more technical term for this?”

“It’s a law,” he said. “Standing in a ring makes you think of laws even when you are the most lawless creature in the patch. You used the mirror for the truth and not for vanity. The bill is that you now owe the town your true story.”

“For how long?” I asked, foolish as a child measuring the ocean with a cup.

“For as long as Brill is amused,” he said, which is to say for as long as it takes him to become bored with you, which is to say: longer than you think, shorter than you fear, exactly the amount of a summer that leaves you on a porch in September knowing the shape of cold.

“What kind of true story,” I said, and the ring did that gasping laugh our kind does when a person has gotten cute with specificity. He shrugged.

“The kind that pulls shame out like splinters and shows people how to stop apologizing to air,” he said. “You already do it. Do it publicly. Bring your bowl, bring your bands, bring your friend with the letters on the fridge. The town will come because the town likes to see itself be brave.”

“I don’t like spectacles with me in them,” I said.

“You have been in a spectacle since you made a home here,” he said. “Richmond Hill is a stadium if you stand on it wrong. Make your stadium cosy. Teach the bleachers to purr.”

“I can’t conjure more kittens,” I said, misreading him on purpose, because that is the only way to keep from doing what someone wants you to do immediately, which is an important muscle for a fairy who likes her own mind.

“You won’t have to,” he said, and his smile made me think of rain gutters. “Sometimes you invite something by being it. You have made a habit of gentleness. Habits are invitations with lace on them.”

“I will charge someone for the lace,” I said.

He laughed for real and expected me to leave, and I did, because lingering after you get your omen makes it look like you want to be told again and I do not. The city had wrung itself out and hung itself up. The sky was raw as a scraped knee but proud of itself. Brill had not checked in. He was folding himself somewhere into something that people would unwittingly unfold, and then he would tell them to be flattered when he wore them like a shirt.

We held the first story-night on the patch of lawn behind the band shell where the grass is always damp even when the days are cruelty. Layla printed a sign that said Tell It Like You Mean It, and below that, in smaller letters: No Jokes That Punch Down; No Jokes Sold As Therapy. Mr. Li brought a thermos the size of a child and handed everyone cups whether they wanted them or not. The brass players came because brass likes to sound like punctuation, and we needed punctuation more than we needed answers. I placed the white bowl on a hummingbird table and made it not milk. I made it water with the memory of milk, because I am not an idiot and I know an invitation when I have already written it. The mirror lay face down and showed me a fox if I wanted to think about it.

The first person up was the girl in the red shirt from the patio, whose chair scrape I had not forgotten. She had a hand on her stomach as if she was hiding a wound and a grin that did not know it was a weapon yet. She told a story about being the loud friend and about how sometimes you want to be the quiet friend and be asked to speak, and the chorus raised itself at the right place, which was when she said: I learned to leave my laugh at home and I came back and it had starved. The second was the man with the briefcase, who had nothing to declare but a father who didn’t say anything nice until he turned seventy and then said everything too often, and somehow it was lovely when he admitted that when the compliments came he despaired because he had been practicing without them for too long. We all laughed where we should, which meant we didn’t laugh where we shouldn’t, which is a discipline that comes like music if you listen.

Brill did not come in a coat of himself. He came as a whisper in the trees that carried the one-liners you tell when you are tired of earnestness, and then he went away because the oaks did not like it. He put two boys in the back into that mood where you want to say something clever and cruel so that the circle will notice you, and the boys swallowed the impulse and spoke about their mothers instead, which is the kind of miracle no church says is a miracle because it would wreck the hymns. He started a rumor in the corner that the bowl would turn anyone who looked into it into a cat for a week, and we let that rumor circulate because it gave the children practice in not believing what made their fur stand up.

It happened when the third reader, an auntie of no ring at all but of all the aunties the world makes for itself, stood up and said, “My brother died laughing and I am angry about it,” which is a sentence that tries to be a paragraph and fails only because it doesn’t have enough breaths in it. The kittens came then. Not from my pockets and not from the bushes but from the fact that a thing needed them. They came as if they had been stationed in gutters and under porches and on the ledges of basement windows, waiting for a note. Twenty, then fifty, then enough to make you feel like your ankles had become interesting property. They weren’t a flood. Floods panic. This was a tide. They came and sat and blinked and not one of them made a sound beyond a purr so deep it tickled the worm-castings.

No one screamed because the story had taught them something already. A child laughed and then clapped both hands over their mouth because they’d been told no we are listening and had learned that being shushed is a kind of attention if you do it with love. The auntie told us about the funeral and about the awful thing the cousin said that made everyone pretend to enjoy it and about the way that laughter felt like it was lifting her like a crane and then put her down somewhere she didn’t recognize. She told us about how she had still cooked and folded and clocked in and out and how sometimes you want an audience automatically the way a wound wants air, and how that is not the same as healing. The kittens leaned against her ankles as if she had not noticed she was a building that needed reinforcement. The purr was an architecture.

Layla caught my eye at the moment when the first cat looked at me and refused to be a metaphor. “You did this,” she mouthed. I wanted to lie and say no it was the weather because weather is always a good scapegoat. I wanted to tell the truth the way Uncle told me to and say yes, this is what follows me when I am good. I shrugged, which is another way of saying I am attempting to tolerate responsibility without choking on it.

Brill tested us. It is either a vice or a loyalty with him. He sent through the crowd a line about women and grief that would have laid ten aunties open like fish for market if it had gone where it meant to, and the line hit the purr and slid off. He tried with the children: a joke about librarians that would have made the kids look at Layla as if she kept secrets not for them but against them, and the joke caught in the fur that was now like grass and fell to pieces as if a child had taken it apart to see what it was made of and found only air and spit. He left because there is only so long you can talk to a room that has learned to prefer listening.

After, when people were winding down and wiping eyes with the hems of clean sleeves and returning the cups to Mr. Li who somehow had more in the thermos than he had started with, I moved through the cats as if I were one of them. The key sang. I put it in the bowl because I needed to know if the world would let me. It nested like a fish in a still pond. A kitten stretched and yawned and put a paw in the water and hissed because cats must try everything and must complain when everything is what it is. The uncle’s advice had been a clutch of thorns and I had grabbed it anyway, and my palms were full of stings and I felt whole.

It could have ended there, in the soft, and because it could, it didn’t. A voice cut across the grass, not Brill’s but the one he uses when he wants to sound like an authority and not like a friend. “Permit?” it said, which is not a fairy word unless we are laughing. Three municipal workers in rain jackets held clipboards as if they had brooms hidden in them, and they had come on an errand that had the smell of his mouth on it. “This is a public green,” the tallest said in the tone of a person who has had to memorize a new script and is not sure whether the audience has learned the call-and-response. “You are… gathering.”

“We are,” Layla said, and stepped forward because that is her shape in a crisis—it’s a step, it’s a forward, and none of us has gotten tired of it yet.

“You need a permit for any public performance,” he said, and the word performance tasted the way old plastic tastes if you chew on it by mistake.

“What if it’s a public grief,” the auntie asked him, so mild you would have missed the point if you had not taken a job where points are your staple.

He looked down at his form. The water from his cuffs dripped exactly where you would expect it to, which told me that magic had not reached those hems yet. “We have had a complaint about cats,” he said, as if anyone in the history of this region had not.

“Kittens,” Mr. Li said, in a tone that did not commit to either mischief or obedience.

I sensed in the close air the shape of Brill’s grin, somewhere behind that man’s left shoulder. Not a possession. A sponsorship. He had found another seam: the one where the rules keep us decent and also keep us small. He had filed a complaint, because even kings used to send a bailiff before they sent a blade, and he is nothing if not a king without furniture. He wanted me to argue on the grounds he had offered, then twist, then have to audience my way out while he held a stopwatch.

I did not argue. I put my hands together as if I were praying to the idea of the city, and I said, to the clipboards and whatever was listening through them, “We are a story hour. We have a librarian, we have a book, we have a bowl of water and some cats who are sitting as if they were being read to. We are within noise bylaws. We have no amplification beyond brass, which in this municipality is sacred. If you would like to issue us a fine, we will pay it in pennies and parties.”

He blinked because that is not how you speak to authority and also because it is exactly how you speak to authority when it is also an auntie in a nice vest. He passed his eyes—poor, tired eyes—over the faces and the fur. His shoulder softened half a millimeter, which is the kind of change that can stop a war. “Just… keep the cats from the playground,” he said, and because the world can be merciful if you feed it the right sentence in the right place, a tabby got up and stretched and led a small pilgrimage of kittens to the other side of the grass. The worker exhaled. “Thank you,” he said to Layla, because she was closest and because she is what you say thank you to when you don’t know the shape of what helped.

When the crowd thinned and it was only us, which is to say the ones who would come back when it got cold and the ones who would bring a neighbor because it felt like cheating to keep this to yourself, I sat on the low wall and put my face in my hands and held my head gently to remind it it belonged to my neck. Layla put an elbow into my side because she knows better than to put a hand on a fairy in public unless you mean to adopt. “You did it,” she said, and then laughed, a little angry because that is her luxury when she knows we are safe for ten minutes. “You made a cat choir. Of course you did.”

“I didn’t,” I said, and then corrected myself because the uncle and the mirror and my own skin demanded it. “I invited. They came.”

“He woke something up,” Mr. Li said, as if Brill were the weather and we were the leaves. “And you told it we were a sanctuary, not a stadium.”

At home the houseplants had organized a coup and decided to look wilty to get my attention. I misted everyone like a benevolent tyrant. The bowl went into the sink and made the note it makes when you put something holy into a place where we do our dullest work. The whisker key lay on the white of the bathtub and warmed the tile like a little sun, sulking because it had not been the star. I told it aloud that everyone gets their turn, which made me sound like a manager I swore I would never be.

The knock at my door came at an hour that does not exist on clocks but exists in bones; it was the hour when the city resets its shock absorbers and wonders whether to creak or sigh. I opened it because I am foolish or brave or because I had already seen who stood on the other side in three different reflections. Brill leaned in the hallway and admired my landlord’s poorly painted baseboards as if he had designed them. He was damp as a dog and brighter than he had a right to be after being thwarted in front of trumpets.

“You’re popular,” he said, not looking at me, as if my popularity were an object he had set down someplace and forgotten.

“So are you,” I said. “With the Parks Department.”

“Don’t pretend bureaucracy isn’t a band I can play,” he said. “You caught that tune, too, I see.”

“We’re all trying to be decent,” I said, which is a sentence that can make you sound smug if you aim it wrong, and which I have practiced saying with my throat shaped like an apology.

He put his shoulder against my doorframe and hummed the first bar of the song that used to call me when I was wild. “I thought you would break the mirror,” he said. “Just to see what happened.”

“I thought you would drink the milk,” I said. “Just to see what happened.”

We grinned at each other like enemies who had inherited the same aunt’s ugly couch and had both secretly decided to love it out of spite. “You’re going to ask me for kindness again,” he said, with the weariness of someone who knows the flavor of their least favorite medicine.

“I am,” I said. “Not because I think you’ll say yes, but because I think the asking is the kind of spell that keeps the doors open.”

“Doors,” he said, and looked past me at the key on the tub. “You and your keys.” He lifted his chin. “Careful with your kittens, Tammy-Tam. People are going to put their mouths on them and call it cute when what they’re doing is learning that softness is a vending machine.”

“I have a price,” I said. “I always did. I’ve made it clear. I take the moment you would have regretted and give you back an hour you can live in. They can send the bill to me.”

“And one day,” he said, and the hallway light flickered because even electricity likes drama, “one day, I will turn you into what you make. I’ll do it cleanly. I’ll do it with consent. I’ll make you a kitten and I’ll hold you in my hands and you’ll see that softness is a blade too when you’re not swinging it. Then we will call it even.”

“Not today,” I said, and it sounded like a prayer because I had Auntie Bellflower in my chest where she had told me to put her, and because the uncle’s burr had gotten under my nail and made thinking easy.

He pushed off from the frame and walked down the hallway and did not look back because he knows better than to give me that victories in such small currencies. “Soon,” he said, a promise or a lie, and if there’s a difference with him I have never found it.

I closed the door and sat on the floor because sometimes you have to be low to feel high. The city breathed. The cats outside handled their wars and their courts and their romance under parked cars like the princes they are. I cleaned the bowl until it lost the last trace of sweet. I put my hand flat on the mirror until my face blurred into a truth that looked just like me. I thought about the story I owed and what it would cost to tell it right, which is always the price you pay when you come from people who think secrets are seasoning and you decide to be a meal somebody can eat without guessing spices.

In the morning the radio said that the headline was Kittens Disrupt Community Event, and Layla sent me a picture of the paper and a caption that read: they spelled disrupt wrong, and I sent back a picture of the bowl and a caption that read: they spelled kitten wrong. Auntie Bellflower sent no note because she knows the value of letting you not be praised. The uncle had left a burr on my windowsill, which is a joke where he comes from and a blessing where I live. I put it in my pocket next to the copper wire and thought about the parade of our ordinary days, and about how a joke can be a kindness if you remember to put a chair under the part of you that is going to sit down when the laugh shakes you. Then I went out to buy milk. It wasn’t for me. I told myself that. But I felt the part of me that wanted to lap at the brim and be forgiven for once without doing any work and I told that part, steady now, we only ever get the miracles we are willing to clean up after.

Chapter Five

The supermarket had that after-rain fluorescence that makes fruit look evangelized and the tile aisles feel like a ferry. The refrigeration units breathed clean, and the fans above the rotisserie chickens sounded like the tired wings of angels who had taken a side gig. I walked past pyramid stacks of nectarines that promised to bruise if you looked at them wrong and let my hand hover over cartons of cream that wanted to be in coffee and argued about it. The milk took up a full wall and still a woman beside me sighed like there was not enough of it in the world. I picked the one that pours best, which is a knowledge you only get if you pour for others often. The label had a cow on it that looked so content it was almost indecent, and someone had written on the shelf tag in pencil: local-ish. A worker with the posture of a retired dancer had left a mop leaning against an endcap that bragged about loyalty points. I looked at the loyalty points and saw Brill in them. He had taught the store to remember your third choice and offer it first, as if it were a summer fling circling back to propose.

“Want a sample?” a man in a vest said to me, his hat hatched with rain salt and his eyes bright with the manic conviction of someone who has been told to be jovial or perish. He held out a thimble cup of yogurt in a flavor named after a dessert that should not be a yogurt. Behind him stood a boy with a face like a door left ajar, hopeful and wary.

“Not today,” I said, gently enough that we were both let off the hook. The boy reached for my milk without thinking and then did think and took his hand back like it had found a hot pan. I smiled at him the way you smile at the part of a child that has not yet decided to remain a child.

At the registers a woman with a bruise on her arm shaped like a number loaded up a conveyor belt with seventeen cans of beans and two boxes of cereal with cartoon bees that look like they know your bank balance. The cashier looked like he had been born at his station and not minded. The monitor flickered and began to suggest recipes: beans with bravado, beans with apology, beans with the sentence you are not daring enough today and the next day you will be too careful. It was Brill’s work, small and corrosive, disguised as convenience. The woman made a face like she’d been offered a compliment by someone she didn’t want to owe.

“Do you want me to turn it off?” the cashier asked, and you could hear he was repeating a line, not offering a kindness. I pulled the mirror out of my bag under the pretense of checking the way the rain had arranged my hair, and tilted it so the screen saw itself for half a second. The recipes broke into numbers and then into letters and then into a sort of satisfied hum the way a cat will climb into a box, decide it is adequate, and sleep.

She caught my eye and nodded once. “Thanks,” she said to no one, so the debt had a place to sit that was not my name.

On the way out I passed a pyramid of mangoes that had started to smell like a memory of a country I have never been to, and a brand ambassador offered me a card that would build a tally of my habits and present me with a joke about them every Friday. I declined. He did not insist; probably he had been to one of our nights and recognized my face, or else he recognized my refusal as a type he feared to catalog.

Outside the rain had made a lace out of traffic and pinned it to the day. Cars hissed secrets at each other. The bus exhaled in the way of large animals pretending to be infrastructure. A woman in a green coat tilted her head to watch a squirrel execute a precision jump from one tree to another and then whisper, with feeling, “Showoff,” and the squirrel executed a second jump that you could only call an encore. I walked north with milk hip-braced against my side and wondered if I was ready to show anything to anyone tonight.

The bill for the mirror lay in my mouth, a coin I couldn’t swallow. Layla would be at the library making a sign that was both solemn and silly, because if you don’t do both you are making religion or you are making a party and neither will do. Mr. Li would arrive with his thermos and his patient hands. The auntie with the jaguar-grief would come because she had discovered that her laugh could be used for something besides carrying other people’s weight. The municipal worker would come without his clipboard and with a fold-up chair, because I had seen a future in which he discovered the joy of being anonymous in a crowd of people who had decided to be known.

I wanted to open the ring and ask Bellflower what kind of truth counts as tender and what kind counts as reckless. I wanted to be told that I could pay my debt with interest and then not think about it again. The fence considered me as I passed, all spruce eye and resin eyelid, and did not wink. The clover hissed a warning in a tiny voice. The backyard smelled like pies and mischief remembered. The ring can be stingy when you are about to publicly remove your own fur.

At home I set the milk on the counter with the carefulness I reserve for gifts and curses. The houseplants had rallied and did not require my drama. The whisker key thrummed on the tile as if it were counting down to a trick it desperately wanted to perform. The mirror lay face-up, catching the light that had more gray in it than it should have, showing me both the crinkles at my eyes and the part of me that still looks like the girl who walked into the ring without asking and forgot what to call herself until someone with a spider’s patience spun the syllables back into a sound.

The truth I owed was a knot with my teeth in it. The first strand was winter. It was the winter I have already mentioned, the one where a boy was turning himself into a story because he had been told with such conviction that he was a story that he believed it more than the heat in his fingers. He had walked out onto Bond Lake in boots named after mountains, liked the music of the ice when it sang its submarine songs, and asked the cold to make him into something worth repeating. His mother had found his bike leaning against a fence like a faithful dog. I found his hat caught on a reed where the water was too thin for anything but foolhardy birds.

I have a way with small things. I do not have a way with boys making larger choices. I stood on the shore and tasted the air and did the calculus you do when you are about to move without moving. I took the thread from my own dress and tied it around my wrist, which is how you anchor yourself to a truth you will want to escape later. I walked out, not onto the ice—never onto the ice; we are not that arrogant—but into the part of the lake that knows what to do with names. I said his name and heard that it had been left for a while in the care of a willow and had gotten sticky with sap. I called him back with the tone you use for cats and stubborn gods. He looked at me as if my face was something that only made sense once you warmed up. He said he didn’t want to come. I said that was what stories say, and he was not a story yet. He asked what he would be instead. I said, to my shame, you will be alive, which is not an answer and too often a sentence. I did a wrong thing and then a right thing. The wrong thing was to take his hand without asking. The right thing was to give him a joke one of the aunties had taught me that belongs to winter: What do you call it when the wind holds your breath for you? Kindness. He came. The ice muttered but did not crack. The willow shook its shoulders and the sap let him go.

After that, things in the city started to notice me in the way of animals with favors to return and grudges to nurse. The aunties met me in the ring and told me my habit had been set. They said: you will be the one with the kittens, you will be the one who answers the worst versions of what-ifs with soft yeses. They laughed at me kindly and gave me the whisker key and told me that one day I would have to buy myself back from the bargain I had struck with myself. I asked them for the return policy. They said: you have to tell the truth out loud where the judging is easy and the mercy is hard. I said: so, the internet? Bellflower hit me with a blade of grass and told me I was getting too clever.

The second strand was a girl named Keira who did not want help and did not need it until she did. She stood at a bus stop and let the rain collect on her eyelashes and pretended not to hear when the man beside her took a tone with her shoulders. He used the voice that says I am joking and you are not very fun. He used the body that says I am reaching for you and you should be flattered. The bus came and did not stop because it had been bewitched by a scheduling error. I did the thing I do. I kittened him. It made it a scene when what she had wanted was to be invisible. He went small and soft and confused and his friends hooted and pretended to be surprised that he had a whine on him. She looked at me with fury and gratitude and said, my problem is that I am always being taken into other people’s jokes without being asked whether I am funny. Later she brought me a doughnut with cinnamon and sugar like home and told me her name and the names of the women who would call me if they needed me. That is a debt you pay with a ledger you aren’t allowed to keep.

There is also a third strand that I do not tell, but I will have to tell, because the uncle said so and because Brill already knows the shape of it. It is Brill and me in a backyard with laundry that smells like lemon and an afternoon that thought it could go on forever. It is him asking me what I have that isn’t kindness and me showing him the edge on it. It is him taking that edge and teaching himself how to cut without making a mess. It is the first time I heard his joke land inside a person I love, and the first time I failed to block it because I had been proud and late. It is a thing that I will say tonight if the milk looks back at me and tells me to.

By dusk the park had wrung itself out and combed its hair. The red ants had made a detour around the cap of a bottle someone had left, and the crows had called a meeting and then postponed it due to air. The children’s section of the library had been disassembled and reassembled into a ghazal of blankets and chairs. Layla’s sign read: Pay Attention, With Snacks. The brass players did their mouthpiece stretches and looked like men blowing kisses into their own hands, which is not a bad habit if you need to mine affection from the air. Kittens arrived without fanfare and arranged themselves like punctuation at the ends of rows.
